story: Mr Corbyn has been criticised for meeting IRA members during the Troubles (Image: Thierry Monasse  Getty Images)The former head of MI6 said last year that Britain would be less safe if Mr Corbyn was in charge.Pressed in a rare interview this weekend to explain his view, Sir Richard said: I think someone coming from my background is troubled by Jeremy Corbyn's past associations, some of which I find surprising, and worrying.He may have abandoned them now, but I don't think you can entirely dump your past.He's enthusiastically associated himself with groups and interests which I would not say were the friends of the British nation.                May launches CHARM OFFENSIVE for Labour votersSir Richard did not name any of the groups but Mr Corbyn has been criticised for meeting IRA members during the Troubles and for sharing platforms with anti-Israeli Palestinian extremists.Sir Richard denied security officials would withhold information from Mr Corbyn if he won the election because it would have been the democratic decision of the British people to make him Prime Minister.In that position, you have to treat him as PM, said Sir Richard.I'm expressing concerns about him and his political past which I think are pretty extensively shared by a lot of people.He also dismissed claims by Corbyn allies that a hostile deep state was working against Labour.It's rubbish, Sir Richard told Sky News&rsquo Sophy Ridge on Sunday.Sir Richard Dearlove's comments triggered a furious reaction from Labour (Image: Cate GillonGetty Images)I think every government has been loyally served by the British security and intelligence community and I imagine that every future government would be loyally served.I don't particularly like this concept of the 'deep state', that it's some 'sinister power'. It's conspiratorial thinking which I think is inappropriate in a political context in a modern democracy.Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell hit back at the claims about Mr Corbyn, telling Sky News: I'm not surprised. This is a member, a reactionary member of the establishment, so I don't think he'd welcome a Labour government.I think he should spend his retirement in quiet contemplation of the role that he played with regard to the Iraq war where over half a million people, at least, were killed.Referring to the Chilcott inquiry into the conflict, Mr McDonnell added: He (Sir Richard) was strongly criticised as the head of an organisation whose intelligence took us into that war so I think he should have a bit of humility about the judgements he makes about iniduals and others in the future.Sir Richard headed Britain's overseas spy agency MI6, the Secret Intelligence Service, from 1999 to 2004. The Chilcott inquiry was scathing about MI6's presentation of flawed, bogus and over-egged intelligence about Saddam Hussein's military ambitions in the run-up to the US-UK 2003 invasion.

title: brexit wooferendum dog march Alastair campbell Daniel Elkan london
story: Remainers have been out in full force around London today  (Image: REUTERS)The Wooferendum Dog March was attended by many including actor Peter Egan, who has five dogs, and author and politician Alastair Campbell, who brought his five-month-old Caviliar King Charles Spaniel puppy to the march which also saw him demand crowds to &ldquokeep fighting for a People&rsquos Vote.Mr Campbell, 61, also addressed crowds at a rally and later said politicians were scared of having a people's vote on the outcome of Brexit negotiations.Speaking of the event afterward, he said: &ldquoIt's a very British sort of thing - people love their animals and there are serious animal welfare concerns with Brexit, but the reason I wanted to come is that I do think the people's vote has got to happen.He also took a swipe at the Prime Minister.Mr Campbell, 61, also addressed crowds at a rally and later said politicians were scared  (Image: REUTERS)He said: &ldquoThey know the will of the people is changing, if Theresa May can't even unite her party around this vision of Brexit, how is she going to unite the country.Tiffany Haynes, a dog walker from London, brought Welsh Collie Megan with her to today's march, wearing the sign &lsquoCollies think Brexit is for wallies&rsquo.She said: &ldquoI think this is a nice idea for a protest, it's a clever way of doing it because dogs make light of politics and bring people together.People can relate to each other more with their dogs. story: Kate, left, is back at Sarah's side (Image: NC)Kate Waddington, the image consultant who parted with Sarah eight years ago amid reports of acrimony over unpaid fees, is once again acting as her informal adviser.Miss Waddington, 52, has been made a director of Ginger &amp Moss, a company set up by Sarah to explore business opportunities, including the sale of quintessentially British flavoured tea which the Duchess plans to promote in America.A friend said: She is helping the Duchess out on a few things they go back a long way. title: Brexit news Theresa May SNP Ian Blackford second independence referendum UK EU withdrawal
story: The Scottish National Party (SNP) have warned Theresa May they will back a second Brexit referendum tied to a new independence vote for Scotland.&nbspSNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford insisted his party will not let the British Government drag Scotland out of the European Union and will continue to demand membership of the single market and customs union are guaranteed.Speaking to Sophy Ridge on Sky News, Mr Blackford said: We will not and cannot be dragged out of the single market and the customs union against our will.We are not playing politics with Brexit because it&rsquos too important. It&rsquos about jobs, it&rsquos about prosperity and we know if there&rsquos a hard Brexit, if we&rsquore out of the single market and the customs union, there&rsquos a real threat to jobs in Scotland and indeed throughout the rest of the United Kingdom.                Secret plans for &lsquoCAR CRASH BREXIT&rsquo being prepared by Downing Street                &lsquoIt&rsquos obscene!&rsquo EU chiefs planning 20th birthday bash for 'failing'...Mr Blackford also said SNP support for a second Brexit referendum if Scotland is granted permission to hold a fresh vote on the independence of the nation.A Survation survey of 1,013 Scottish voters published by The Sunday Herald showed 50 percent would now vote to break up with the UK in the event of a hard Brexit.The SNP MP continued: What we are saying is that if there is to be a People&rsquos Vote then we need to make sure our position is protected.We must have the right that if we are being dragged out of the EU if we are dragged out of the single market and the customs union, we have the ability to determine our own future.Brexit news: Mr Blackford warned Mrs May Scotland will not be dragged out of the EU (Image: SKY NEWS&bullBBC)Mr Blackford also urged the Prime Minister to consider seeking a bespoke trade arrangement for Scotland similar to the one her negotiators are trying to strike to avoid a hard border in Northern Ireland.He added: We all must do everything that we can to support the delivery of the Good Friday Agreement.Nothing that should happen out of Brexit should impair the Good Friday Agreement but if it means there is a bespoke deal for Northern Ireland there is no reason why the Prime Minister shouldn&rsquot be looking at putting the same circumstance on the table for Scotland.Earlier this week SNP First Minister Nicola Sturgeon claimed she would support a Brexit People's Vote in the event Mrs May called for one but argued a second referendum on EU membership would not guarantee salvation for Scotland.She said &ldquoThe Tories are leading Scotland to disaster and the last few days we&rsquove had warnings of recession, medicine shortages, pressure on food supply.&ldquoWe&rsquove seen the cancellation of a clinical trial at the Golden Jubilee Hospital. But that for me makes this point clearer than ever.&ldquoScotland needs the option of independence because only independence guarantees that these things can&rsquot be imposed on us against our will.

title: Brexit news update BBC Andrew Marr Brandon Lewis Northern Ireland border
story: The Conservative MP was asked whether he believed the UK Government was closed to a Brexit deal and claimed he was confident Theresa May would get an agreement with Brussels by the end of the year.But when BBC's Andrew Marr asked him if the Prime Minister was prepared to implement further regulatory checks between Great Britain and Northern Ireland as a result of a potential hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, the debate escalated into a fiery row.&nbspThe Tory Party Chairman initially replied: &ldquoWe&rsquove got a very clear policy on the table.&ldquoWe&rsquove outlined through the White Paper how we think this could work.                FINAL COUNTDOWN: Dublin and Brussels TURN HEAT UP on May &ldquoIt does deliver on the referendum and it gives a really strong free trade agreement with what is arguably the biggest trading bloc, our partners in Europe.&ldquoI think the Prime Minister will get a deal that delivers on that, and we&rsquoll bring that back to Parliament in the next couple of months.As the BBC presenter was unhappy with Mr Lewis' response, he reprimanded the Tory MP for failing to address his original question.&nbspMr Marr said: &ldquoThat is absolutely not my question Brandon Lewis. Would you be prepared to accept further regulatory checks as between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK, or not?The Tory MP promptly hit back accusing the BBC host of working in hypotheticals and claimed he was being clear about the facts.Brexit news: Brandon Lewis and Andrew Marr in a heated debate over the future of Northern Ireland (Image: BBC)He replied: &ldquoWell, the difference between my answer and your question, Andrew, is you&rsquore working in hypotheticals and I&rsquove been very clear about the facts.&ldquoThere is one clear plan on the table, that&rsquos the one from the Government.&ldquoAs the Prime Minister said, the EU have got to come back to us on that. I think that&rsquos a deal that works and that&rsquos the deal we&rsquore focussed on getting.The Tory MP added no Prime Minister would want to ever see a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland and said he was prepared to reassure DUP leader Arlene Foster on the issue.The row comes as Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar gave Theresa May a Brexit ultimatum on Friday when he claimed the Prime Minister had two weeks to convince Brussels and Dublin the UK is ready to agree to a Brexit deal.Mr Varadkar said he remained hopeful there will be decisive progress in the next two weeks to conclude a Brexit deal but warned there is still more work to be done.He said:&nbsp&ldquoThere will be a summit in two weeks in Brussels that will be a time for us to take stock.&ldquoI would be hopeful at that point that there would be decisive progress allowing us to conclude an agreement by November.That remains to be seen yet. I think there is a fair bit of work to be done.&ldquoIt's increasingly important that we conclude a deal sooner rather than later.

title: Brexit news Lloyds bank Inga Beale Andrew Marr show relocate Brussels UK EU withdrawal
story: Lloyd's CEO Inga Beale revealed the company was accelerating plans to move insurance contracts to its Brussels subsidiary to protect business from the impact of Brexit.Ms Beale insisted they were forced to create a new European Union HQ in Belgium because of the risk to 15 percent of its contracts with European clients.Speaking on The Andrew Marr Show, she said: If we can&rsquot serve our contracts, we are going to be transferring those contracts hopefully to our Brussels subsidiary, so we have a contingency plan.&ldquoIn fact, we are accelerating that plan because it seems to me we might be closer to a no deal than we were.                May on track for BATTLE for Scotland as SNP gears up for independenceMs Beale also said Lloyd's and other financial companies in the UK were lobbying the British Government to ensure business working cross-Channel receive the continuity of contract to avoid any disruption once Britain leaves the EU in March 2019.She claimed the insurance company had been &ldquoforced to establish a second headquarter in Brussels because of Brexit.She continued: Lloyd&rsquos heart is in London but it writes business from all over the world. 15 percent of the business Lloyd&rsquos does comes from the EU markets.Post-Brexit we won&rsquot have the ability to continue offering insurance just from London as before therefore we are opening a subsidiary in Brussels, We wouldn&rsquot have done that if it wasn&rsquot for Brexit. It&rsquos something we have been forced to do.Brexit news: Lloyd's boss Inga Beale said they are accelerating contract transfers to Brussels (Image: BBC)Ms Beale added: Going forward we&rsquove got our solution and I think you&rsquoll see for financial firms all across the city, they&rsquoll have to have some people based outside of London. But a lot of that money will still flow through London.Another thing we&rsquore concerned about is servicing the old contracts. We will potentially lose the ability to pay any claims on old contracts and that&rsquos what we&rsquore lobbying the Government for, to say &lsquocan you resolve this continuity of contract? how can we serve our customers beyond Brexit?&rsquoBut not all British companies appear to be negative about the future outside of the European Union, with Unilever&nbspbosses last week scrapping plan to move headquarters to Amsterdam.&nbspMajor shareholders in the company were reportedly angered by the plans to move out of the UK and potentially cut it off from the benefits of financing in the City of London.Former Brexit minister David Jones said: &ldquoBritain passes the Marmite test. After the announcement that Unilever is keeping its headquarters in London, this is another massive vote of confidence in the UK after Brexit.&ldquoIt&rsquos a clear sign that successful businesses see a bright future in Brexit Britain.

title: Brexit news update Pimlico Plumbers sign Charlie Mullins latest
story: Speaking on LBC, the Pimlico Plumbers boss told Andrew Castle he will not take down his offensive anti-Brexit sign until the Government calls for a second referendum on leaving the European Union.Mr Mullins argued he would be prepared to take the matter to court and even end up in prison over his anti-Brexit cause.The sign - which reads B******s to Brexit - was deemed as unrelated to Mr Mullins' company by Lambeth Council who requested the sign to be removed as soon as possible.But Mr Mullins refuses to take the sign down on the basis Brexit relates to his and every other business in the country that will be economically affected by the decision to leave the EU.                'May's plan is B******S!' Even this FERVENT Remainer condemns May plan                'Is it wise?' Pimlico Plumbers founder grilled over anti-Brexit signHe said: Quite clearly Brexit it very much about our business. It's not coming down.I'm a Remainer and looking for a People's Vote, and it's not coming down until we get that.If it means going to prison over it, then that's what I'll do.&ldquoWe need to make a stand for businesses and I don&rsquot believe that British businesses or just normal people should see their livelihoods go away just because Theresa May wants to leave the EU.Brexit news: Charlie Mullins claims he is prepared to go to prison over his anti-Brexit sign (Image: )The millionaire plumber pledged his support for a second&nbspBrexit&nbspreferendum predicting British voters will reverse the results of the 2016 referendum.Mr Mullins, who in March announced he would support the Lib Dem leader Vince Cable in his attempts to stop Brexit, has long claimed to leave the&nbspEuropean Union&nbspwould have negative effects on the country.Speaking to&nbspLBC over the summer, the Pimlico Plumbers tycoon said: We need a second referendum. We need to speak out.I'm telling you now, we won't be leaving the EU. I don't care what anybody says. We won't be leaving because the British people aren't that stupid any more.Mr Mullins insisted the people would be unhappy if the Government failed to set up a new referendum on the final terms of the Brexit withdrawal agreement struck with Brussels.He also reiterated the UK economy would suffer from leaving the bloc: People are going to be very unhappy if we don't have a second vote.We now know the facts. We're not prepared to put up with what we're being told, lies, ahead of us. What bit do the government not understand? Brexit is not good for the economy and for the people.But a Deltapoll survey of 1,094 adults published in August suggested that one in four Briton want the Government to deliver Brexit, with only 31 percent backing a new in-out referendum.Asked whether the UK should simply leave the EU on March 29, 2019 40 percent of respondents said they were in favour &ndash including 19 percent of former Remain voters.

title: Brexit news update Peoples Vote second referendum Sir Alan Duncan latest
story: Speaking on BBC Radio 5's Pienaar's Politics, the Tory MP dismissed claims the UK could re-join the European Union a few years Brexit was fully implemented by a deal with Brussels.Sir Alan argued, despite some people might be surprised by the final agreement Prime Minister Theresa May will reach at the end of the negotiations, the 2016 Referendum result will nonetheless be implemented with a new contract with the EU.&nbspHe said: &ldquoI think once we&rsquove left, we&rsquove left.&ldquoThere&rsquos no doubt that at the referendum people were voting for a concept rather than a contract.                Sting and Ed Sheeran JOIN Bob Geldof's latest anti-Brexit attack                Sturgeon reveals plan to SINK Brexit and break up UK&ldquoAnd now we&rsquore having to define that contract so inevitably maybe some people will say &lsquoOh I didn&rsquot see that coming&rsquo.&ldquoBut then that&rsquos what referenda do and we are bound by the referendum so we are going to have to negotiate the best deal for the country consistent with the outcome of the referendum.Asked whether there could be a possibility of a second Brexit vote - as called for by supporters of the People's Vote - Sir Alan quickly provided BBC host John Pienaar with a simple reason a second referendum with the option to remain in the EU could never be provided by the Government.He said: &ldquoI think that&rsquos fanciful. A three-way referendum?Brexit news: Sir Alan Duncan claims legislation for a second referendum would never pass by March 29 (Image: TRT&bull)&ldquoI mean, first of&nbspall,&nbspyou&rsquove got to get the legislation through and it ain&rsquot going to be though before the 29th March.&ldquoSo it ain&rsquot going to happen.It comes as Prime Minister Theresa May renewed her pledge to block calls for a second vote on Brexit at the Conservative Party Conference claiming a second referendum would be a politicians' vote.Mrs May said: &ldquoThere are plenty of prominent people in British politics &ndash in Parliament and out of it &ndash who want to stop Brexit in its tracks.&ldquoTheir latest plan is to hold a second referendum. They call it a People&rsquos Vote.&ldquoBut we had the people&rsquos vote. The people voted to leave.&ldquoA second referendum would be a politicians&rsquo vote: politicians telling people they got it wrong the first time and should try again.&ldquoThink for a moment what it would do to faith in our democracy if &ndash having asked the people of this country to take this decision &ndash politicians tried to overturn it.&ldquoThose of us who do respect the result &ndash whichever side of the question we stood on two years ago &ndash need to come together now.&ldquoIf we don&rsquot &ndash if we all go off in different directions in pursuit of our own visions of the perfect Brexit &ndash we risk ending up with no Brexit at all.

title: france emmanuel macron Gerard Collomb resignation Bruno Cautres
story: Macron is clinging onto power following the shock departure of his steadfastly loyal interior minist (Image: )The shock resignation of Mr Collomb, Mr Macron&rsquos most senior cabinet member, poses a fresh dilemma for the Frenchman - whether to replace him or use it as an opportunity to reshuffle his team.The resignation itself was not entirely shocking, but it was the way it was handled and the subsequent mockery of Mr Macron&rsquos leadership style that gave the French President yet another problematic month.And the timing could not be worse as Mr Macron approaches the second phase of his five-year presidency.When Mr Macron took office he devised a plan which was split into two phases.                Brigitte Macron hosts Queen Letizia in wearing stunning cream dress                Queen Letizia STUNS in quirky cocktail dress for night out with MacronThe first phase, which kicked off when he took office, consisted of implementing tough reforms on tax, labor laws, training, benefits and pensions to revive the economy.'Phase Two', highlighting the successes of his reforms in the run-up to the 2022 presidential election, would then be launched around mid-2019.Bruno Cautres, a professor at Paris-based Sciences-Po institute, said: &ldquoChaos of news, scandals, personal ambitions, all these very human factors have upended Macron&rsquos plans.&ldquoEither he continues to repair every leak or takes a big step to restore stability.Mr Macron has been mocked for his organisational skills (Image: )Despite Mr Macron pleading with Mr Collomb not to leave and shockingly refusing to accept his notice, he left anyway and spoke of his desire to leave Mr Macron&rsquos cabinet &ldquoas soon as possible.The very act of speaking to the French media is considered a debacle in itself, as Mr Macron has banned any member of his team from doing so without his permission.That, teamed with his meticulous leadership style, which caused the French media to nickname him the &ldquomanager-President due to him interfering in minuscule matters, 2am texts and colour-coordinating his timetable in a manner similar to a student approaching exam week has resulted in his popularity taking a nose-e by 30 percent.Mr Collomb is not the only addition to Mr Macron&rsquos cabinet that resigned just 18 months into his presidency.                French minister REFUSES to back down over no deal Brexit claimOther officials in Mr Macron&rsquos team who have stepped down include defence minister Sylvie Goulard and former party chief Richard Ferrand to name a few.French Environment Minister Nicolas Hulot was another who quit, citing huge differences with Mr Macron as his reason, as he added: &ldquoI can&rsquot lie to myself anymorePerfectionist Mr Macron has always envisioned his five-year stint at the top in phases.The first and current consists of the implementation of tax, benefits and pension reforms and labour laws. He planned for the second to be where French voters benefitted from the fruits of those tough changes in the run-up to the 2022 general election.Backbencher Francois Patriat said: &ldquoPhase One was always until June 2019, after the European elections, as all the major reforms would be completed, the team has to stay and finish the job, even if sometimes there are erging views.Despite displaying a lack of control over his own matters, Mr Macron has waded into foreign affairs on several occasions, most recently declaring Britain should be entitled to a second EU referendum &ldquofor sure.This resulted in Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab accusing Mr Macron of &ldquounsavoury political posturing and tactics.

title: putin is mafia boss with nukes
story: ANGERED: Putin (Image: Mikhail SvetlovGetty Images)He said: Vladimir Putin is like a Mafia boss in control of a super power. There are many tyrants running small countries in Africa, but this is a Mafia boss with nukes.Putin has created a Russia where the sole purpose is to enrich the lives of the top people in power at the expense of everyone else.He became a Putin enemy after becoming the biggest foreign investor in Russia through company Hermitage Capital Management until 2005 when he was mysteriously denied re-entry to the country.His lawyer Sergei Magnitsky was beaten to death in prison in 2009 after uncovering that &pound176million of taxes paid by his firm was allegedly stolen by corrupt officials, ending up in the pockets of people tied to the Kremlin across the globe.                WW3 WARNING: Ex-MI6 Chief WARNS Russia could strike deadly attack                Army will take on Russia by train!Mr Browder's subsequent campaigning led to the creation of the Magnitsky Act which allows countries to refuse entry visas and freeze assets of foreign iniduals suspected of money laundering, and it has been adopted by six nations, including the US and UK.It also triggered a series of probes into Russian money laundering across 15 countries, angering Mr Putin. He called for US President Donald Trump to hand over Mr Browder during their joint press conference in Helsinki in July, even though he is now a British citizen residing in the UK.Mr Browder runs Hermitage, in London, at a loss with the main purpose of investigating and campaigning against international corruption. He said: I have two aims - to get justice for Sergei through prosecutions and to get the Magnitsky Act implemented in more countries.The US-born investor has faced many death threats which he says come directly from people linked to the Kremlin. He said: They come in emails, text messages, voicemails.It is not sophisticated. It is like 'we are coming for you' and 'what would you prefer, prison or death?' Given Putin's public and emotional vendetta against me, I receive many threats from different sources in different forms.These people are thugs and brutal and will stop at nothing.He was once warned by the US government of a kidnap plot to get him back to Russia. We took precautions to make sure what was being planned was not possible, he said.Russia has requested seven Interpol arrest warrants.One was almost successful in May when Mr Browder was arrested in Spain as he went to meet a money laundering prosecutor.He was rescued when he sent two tweets from the police vehicle.Mr Browder said: Within two hours the arrest warrant had been cancelled. It was following repeated calls from the media to Interpol and Spanish authorities.He criticised Theresa May's response to the Salisbury poisoning as amateur hour with the crackdown on Russian dirty money through the use of new Unexplained Wealth Orders.                US admiral warns Russia's missiles could strike ANY capital in EuropeMr Putin and the Russian embassy have denied any involvement in corruption and overseas deaths (Image: Mikhail Svetlov  Getty Images)Mr Browder said: They need to hit them full scale if they are going to clean up these economic crimes. They need to bring in real experts.Mr Putin and the Russian embassy have denied any involvement in corruption and overseas deaths.The National Crime Agency said they have over &pound750million of criminal assets restrained, frozen or repatriated linked to the investigation of international corruption.An NCA spokesman said: We have considered around 140 cases where the use of an Unexplained Wealth Order may be the appropriate course of action.A significant number of these are against assets believed to be held by Russian iniduals and we are working to apply for further UWOs as our investigations continue.

title: EU news Italy Matteo Salvini Jean Claude Juncker clash Commission budget latest

title: conservative party brexit unity rod liddle opinion
story: I don’t think Theresa May is going to be on Strictly any time soon. Whoever convinced her it would be dead cool to walk on stage at the party conference and jig about to an Abba song needs a bit of invasive brain surgery, right now.It was like a remake of Re-Animator, or Night Of The Living Dead.There’s no point in Theresa trying to tell us she’s the le and soul of the party and actually a bloody good laugh.We know she isn’t. She’s about as charismatic as an underdone crumpet on a wet Sunday. But she doesn’t need to be Ginger Rogers. She’s the Prime Minister.And you have to give her credit for doggedly sticking to that role. EvenI’m not convinced she’s been doing it terribly well.But on Brexit — God, how mind-numbingly boring the whole thing is — she has a good point.I’m not a fan of her Chequers deal for us to leave the European Union. I think we’re giving too much away. I’d rather have a no-deal exit.But time is pressing. And I’m aware that while we Leavers won the referendum, the margin was comparatively small. So we ought to be gracious and accept a little bit of a compromise. Try to strike a respectable deal with those gangsters from insignicant countries.And a little further down the line, tweak the arrangements a little to suit us better. In the meantime, just strike the deal.And that means getting behind May and presenting a united front to Europe. Most of the Conservative MPs understand that, even the arch-Brexiteers like the excellent Michael Gove.But Bfo the Blundering Bear does not. I’m talking about Boris Johnson. Now he IS fun and good company. But he’s about as likely to become Prime Minister as I am to cop off with Emily Ratajkowski after a few pints and a quick meal at the Chicken Cottage.He has very little support among his political colleagues. He has a lot more among Conservative activists. But very little among voters north of Watford.And yet Bfo was at it again this week. Taking the p**s out of the Prime Minister. And making a rousing speech to his hardcore supporters. Demanding we tell the EU to stuff it.Well, there was a time when we should have told the EU to stuff it — two years ago when we first started negotiations.That time has passed. A lack of confidence from the Government and a ided party let us down.Now is the time to show a bit of unity and wring a deal out of the deathly bureaucrats. Maybe not the Chequers deal — May didn’t mention the word at all during her speech — but a version of it.Otherwise we’ll have a General Election on our hands. One the Tories will lose. And you’ll wake up to find John McDonnell is in charge of your finances and Diane Abbott is Home Secretary.Come on — surely that should concentrate the mind a little Hero of the week is Jane Lunnon, head of a girls’ school in South London.She has stuck the boot into “image-obsessed” reality TV – especially that coven of gurning and pouting imbeciles in Love Island, such as Megan Barton Hanson.Such programmes are “incredibly damaging” to young people, she reckons, calling them “trivial nonsense”.I think Jane is right. And the same goes for all those hyped-up talent shows where people with no talent – just a lust for fame – get judged on their appalling performances by people with no talent.Kids need to know the dference between fame for fame’s sake – and real achievement.Its horrible that Corine Remande has lost the sight in one eye after she was hit by a golf ball during the Ryder Cup.The poor woman was standing among spectators when Brooks Koepka’s tee shot hit her in the face.She’s now threatening legal action against the organisers. She says they didn’t give spectators enough protection.This is ludicrous. What were they supposed to do And what will happen is that in future crowds will be kept even further back from the action. Just because of one horrible accident.Wait until the same thing happens in cricket...The uni magazine said: “It was argued that the loud noise of traditional clapping and whooping pose an issue to students with anxiety or sensory issues. BSL clapping – or, jazz hands – would be a more inclusive form of expression.”With anxiety or sensory issues  What is wrong with these people They are “triggered” by almost everything. Especially by people who have views which dfer from their own.That REALLY triggers them. They shouldn’t be at university. They should be safe at home with mummy and daddy.That old windbag Mahathir Mohamad has been visiting the UK.Lovely to have him, of course. He’s the boss of Muslim-dominated Malaysia and he hates Jews.He was at it again over here. Said they all had “hook noses”.And that they were the cause of all the trouble in the Middle East.He’s allowed his view, of course, evenit is one based on hatred and the ideology of his own interpretation of his religion.But how would it beI said Muslims are the cause of most of the trouble in the world I’d be up before the Old Bill for a hate crime before you could say Islamic State.This is because Asian countries are getting more and more wealthy.I suppose this is a good thing. Problem is, I can’t stand them, the middle class.And the thought of nearly four billion people eating avocado on toast while doing Pilates then listening to Coldplay in their Volvo XCs makes me feel terribly queasy.The human race is being taken over by the legions of the smug. Get me outta here.Visitors to the Telford Exotic Zoo were disappointed by the penguins. They just stood, stock still.This is because they are plastic model penguins. The zoo had been unable to get the real thing.And here’s a tip for the zoo owners. Don’t buy any real penguins, stick to the models.I think plastic penguins would be far better suited to an enclosure of a dozen square yards of shingle with a tiny drainage ditch to bathe in.Why are we allowing zoos like this to open  If I were a real penguin in Telford Exotic Zoo I’d sue them. Or beat them about the head with a flipper.Have you seen Vladimir Putin’s new calendar There he is, standing naked in water, muscles rippling, looking stern.Another one has him cuddling a baby leopard.I hate to say this but isn’t it all a bit... um... camp And now for saying this I’ll probably end up resembling one of the glow sticks the kids buy at funfairs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rooting against cashless britain
story: But in just ten years’ time, kids will find the idea of a porcelain container for metal coins ridiculous — and will be doing their saving on a phone app with cute graphics.Face it, cash is dying out. It is dirty and unhygienic — a report out this week said it is a breeding ground for bugs.There is even a version of Monopoly with debit cards instead of notes. And last month we told you of the  century The Boot pub in Freston, Suffolk, the first boozer in the country to go cashless.This looming death has been around for a while. In August, the Bank of England said it was considering phasing out p and p coins. And ATMs are closing at a rate of  a month.Just  per cent of payments are cash, down from  per cent in . And those payments only account for three per cent in terms of the value of how much is spent.Paying on card has been on the rise ever since Barclaycard launched in , but cards too face being eclipsed by payments on mobile phones. Either way, both mean we need cash less. And that is not a bad thing, right Getting rid of cash would hit criminals and tax evaders hard as they do business in cash to make it harder for authorities to track the movement of money.Businesses would rejoice because they would not have to pay security guards to transport money and would not have to spend ages counting and bagging it.Some also reckon it is easier to keep a tab on finances when spending on cards or apps. You might forget buying that extra round at closing time in the pub, but your phone will always remember. And of course, you get consumer protection when using a credit card, along with reward points or cashback offers.Credit card firms make their money not just from interest payments but from taking a small fee for each transaction — so they offer us incentives to choose their cards. Use an Air Miles card and before long you could have a free flight to Paris or New York.More than a quarter of clothes in the UK are bought online — and you can’t use cash over the internet. As we move even more to buying online and via smartphone apps, cash will be needed less and less. Whether cash dies out in five years or  or  just depends on technology.But many are in no rush to see the back of it — and not just because of nostalgia for their old piggy banks. One consideration is: Can we entirely trust the banks to look after our money  Fraud is soaring as criminals take advantage of security issues around online banking. Banks blame customers but critics say banks need to take responsibility.We have featured victim after victim on The Sun Money columns, and they all say bank staff have turned their backs on them. There are millions of others who need cash simply because they rely on it to pay for things day to day. And it is the less well off or elderly who rely on it the most.Consumer magazine Which  — which has been campaigning against the loss of banks and ATMs — has produced research showing poorer families and older folk are hardest hit.Gareth Shaw of Which  said: “ATM and branch closures are threatening to leave behind the millions who still rely on cash. Our research highlights lower-income families and older generations will be among the worst hit.”In June, services from Visa, one of the three main card providers along with Mastercard and American Express, went down with technical issues — highlighting the risk of being solely reliable on cards and phones. “When the trolley came around on the train and the card payment wasn’t working, the only people who could eat were those with cash,” one banker explained.And what about hospitality workers  The Government has said all tips, evenon cards, must go to staff — but we all know some unscrupulous bosses will not do that. Like many, I prefer to give my tips in cash so I know the waiter or waitress gets it all.Charity collectors often have card machines now but collections for most churches, schools and small local good causes still rely on tins and the rattle of coins.Cash may well be dying out, but I still make sure I always keep some coins in my pocket just in case. And I have older relatives who still feel most comfortable with coins and notes.So until we have a population where everyone feels happy when using a card or phone, I will be rooting against a completely cashless Britain.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn is so thick putin
story: Vladimir Putin heads what is now, for all intents and purposes, a rogue state.The former KGB man treats international law as just rules to be broken.And in all of this, he is aided by useful idiots here in the UK.It’s an old-school Soviet tactic. Find a gullible public figure who will cheerlead for the Russian regime while spreading doubt and misinformation.But even in his wildest dreams, the former KGB man never would have thought he’d have the Leader of the Opposition parroting his propaganda.We can never forget that Jeremy Corbyn’s first response to the Salisbury attacks was to suggest shipping samples to the Russians.Here is a man who wants to be Prime Minister, yet is so blindingly thick that he thinks we should have given Vlad the chance to mark his own homework.The diligent work of the Anglo-Dutch intelligence operation to reveal further evidence of Moscow’s criminality must be applauded. But would the Dutch have even let our security services know about their investigationit meant Corbyn would be briefed on it We’d be a global laughing stock, cut off from our allies for years.Corbyn has done the work of tyrants and totalitarians all his le. And he’d do the same in Downing Street.BRITAIN should match Australia’s commitment to eliminate cervical cancer within the next  years.Their screening and vaccination scheme has brought the number of new cases down to nearly zero, and they intend to finish the job.It is EXACTLY what we should aspire to. Here, this avoidable disease takes nearly a thousand mothers, sisters, daughters and wives each year.They could still be alive.Health Secretary Matt Hancock should set a target for the UK, too.And secure funding to consign cervical cancer to the dustbin of history.DONALD Tusk wasted no time in raining on Theresa May’s post-Conference parade.He knows full well that we will not accept a deal which splits up the UK.And he also knows his comments yesterday make le more dficult for Mrs May — who he pretends to “respect”.And spare us the faux outrage about Jeremy Hunt’s comments. At least the Foreign Secretary is elected by voters, not bureaucrats.Tusk is a walking and talking reminder that we’re better off out.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says remoaners unilever lies
story: When its boss Paul Polman insisted it “had nothing to do with Brexit” they called him a liar.They said it beggared belief he had failed to blame the Leave verdict, as they so desperately wanted.Not that they were unhappy Unilever were going. Far from it. These people now take a warped delight in bad news.But Unilever has changed its mind.It’s staying.If Brexit was to blame for it leaving, as Remainers argued, can we assume Unilever has now decided Brexit will be a roaring success  Or shall we just take Mr Polman at his word The sad reality is that many previously sane, serious, objective politicians, journalists, academics and others have lost their minds since the referendum upended their world.To rubbish or reverse the vote, they have taken to spouting blatant lies and utter drivel.Tomorrow thousands will march on Parliament with their DOGS to demand a second referendum.It won’t be just the hounds barking.IT’S not enough for President Macron that his popularity in France is at a catastrophic low.He seems bent on becoming the most hated man in EU history too.This egomaniac Napoleon styles himself the saviour of the Brussels project, the man who made Britain change its mind.Britain hasn’t. And won’t. But Macron remains the greatest roadblock to a deal benefiting both sides and safeguarding hundreds of thousands of livelihoods.What does he think will happenhe personally engineers a no-deal outcome The world will look with loathing on the little Frenchman whose Olympian self-regard, blinkered love for the EU and refusal to respect our democracy destroyed jobs across the Continent.And what of Irish PM Leo Varadkar Only now, after two years of showboating intransigence, is he apparently waking up to the disaster looming for his economy.Voters will be merciless with both.IMAGINE handing out awards to lawyers for persecuting old soldiers over their actions during The Troubles decades ago. title: grenfell council seize west london homes house social tenants
story: The properties are owned by millionaires and wealthy oligarchs, with drastic overhauls proposed after growing demand for social housing in the west London borough.Kim Taylor-Smith, deputy leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Cha , revealed the increasing need for social housing in the area had been framed by the Grenfell tragedy, which led to the deaths of  people and left hundreds of council tenants homeless in June .Writing to housing minister Kit Malthousem, Mr Taylor Smith said  properties in the area have been empty and unfurnished for more than two years,  of which are amongst some of the most expensive in the borough, including one worth almost £ million.At the same time, many residents are desperate for a place of their own, but cannot afford to rent or buy in the borough in which they were born, live and work, his letter continued.Kensington and Cha was said to have a huge buy-to-leave investment market, meaning properties are bought and left empty, often to accrue value.Mr Taylor Smith added: This disparity does not sit easily with the councils leadership team.An Empty Dwelling Management Orderis required for a local authority to temporarily seize properties and offer them to social tenants, but Mr Taylor-Smith described it as cumbersome, slow and expensive, making its use prohibitive.The use of EDMOs was restricted in  by then communities secretary Eric Pickles, limiting them to empty properties that have become magnets for vandalism, squatters and other forms of anti-social behaviour and had been empty for two years, according to a House of Commons Library briefing paper.But Mr Taylor-Smith claimed the prerequisite for a council to demonstrate vandalism had curtailed the use of EDMOs.We believe that the burdens can be lightened and EDMOs financially incentivised such that it is easier, quicker and financially viable to target all empty properties that could and should be put to use to alleviate pressing housing needs, he wrote.His proposal suggested offering a favourable tax scheme on rent income for owners of propertythey agree to offer the premises to the local authority.Owners should not lose out. We want to collaborate with, not clobber, the property investor, Mr Taylor-Smith wrote.The letter also requested that councils be able to levy a management fee to help cover the costs of taking over the homes.RBKC owned Grenfell Tower and faced criticism after the fire amid accusations that it and the Kensington and Cha Tenant Management Organisation, which ran the block, ignored repeated safety warnings from residents.Theof time taken to rehouse survivors following the disaster was also condemned, with dozens forced to spend months in hotels.In response, the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government said there were no plans to change the system.A spokeswoman said: Local authorities have a range of powers at their disposal to tackle long-term empty homes, and we expect them to use these to best address the needs of their residents.We have no plans to change the existing laws in this area, but are clear that all councils have a duty to provide affordable homes.

title: fry up inside load bread
story: Rolling Rolls in Bridgend, south Wales, serves up a butty containing sausage, bacon, eggs, hash browns and beans - all smothered within a giant loaf.The firm, which specialises in burgers, hot dogs and breakfasts, came up with this unique way to serve the most important meal of the day after a customer recommended it as a challenge. Owner Michelle Preston, , from Pontypridd, said: Someone asked us to start it as a challenge and we thought why not It has proved really popular with customers and so many people have been trying to finish it.Its quite a large breakfast and really its for two people but most people seem to eat the whole thing by themselves. The huge breakfast contains four sausages, four rashers of bacon, four eggs, four hash browns and beans or tomato sauce for £. Extra hungry customers can upgrade for an additional £ to get two pieces of black pudding too.It is then hollowed into a freshly baked loaf of bread.The breakfast is served from the van on Tremains Road until pm on weekdays. The owners are also looking at serving up vegetarian options.

title: one in 20 kids groomed online
story: Adults are bombarding youngsters with explicit material through social media or text messages.Shock figures show that five per cent – one in  - of over-s have received an X-rated chat-up.The revelation comes as Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright told the Tory party conference that online space shouldn’t be immune from controls.He also said: “Unsupervised access to the internet is simply dangerous.We need parents to understand that.”He announced last week that Ministers would consult on ways to regulate the internet later this year and would bring forward legislation next year.The online survey was conducted by the NSPCC, who interviewed , pupils.The children’s charity are calling on the government to introduce an independent regulator to ensure children are better protected through their Wild West Web campaign.Andy Burrows, NSPCC Associate Head of Child Safety Online said: “It’s great to hear the Digital Secretary talking about regulating the internet and how it could work.“For far too long social networking sites have been free to decide how orthey keep children using their s safe.It is finally time for the tech firms to be held accountable for the risks on their sites.”A Home Office spokesperson said the government is working to tackle online grooming.A spokesman said: “As well as giving dedicated law enforcement teams an additional £m in funding, the Home Secretary has demanded the technology industry urgently address the changing scale and nature of abuse online.“How far new online harms legislation goes will be informed by the industry’s response.But we need everyone, whether they are from law enforcement, frontline professionals, the technology industry, charities, parents and schools to play their role in tackling this problem.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may steps up no deal plans
story: The PM wants measures in place to keep Britain movingshe s empty-handed from crunch EU talks.Ministers have identied eight worst case scenarios which could arisewe crash out without an agreement.They include drug, fuel and energy shortages, collapse of the pound and house prices and businesses relocating.But last night Brexiteers claimed Downing Street was in a state of panic over the likely failure of her Chequers plan.They dismissed warnings of chaos as Project Fear reborn for the umpteenth time.A senior No  official has hosted informal dinners with Eurosceptic MP in a bid to get them behind the blueprint, The Sun on Sunday can reveal.Guests were warned of an absolute car crashBritain leaves without a deal on March .The official outlined eight possible scenarios which would trigger a meeting of the governments Cobra emergency committee.The warning has raised eyebrows among some MPs as the official concerned is an avowed Brexiteer.He told a recent gathering: The Remainers might have cried wolf with Project Fear.But just think about the story of the boy who cried wolf.There actually was a wolf - and in the end he ate the boy.Last night Tory MP Jacob Rees-Mogg said: It appears that Downing Street is in a state of panic.It is the job of government to avoid panic, not create it.After Brexit we will maintain control of our own imports.There is no need for shortages so we should remain calm and ensure le carries onFellow Tory Priti Patel added: Theresa May has constantly told us that no deal is better than a bad deal.Only last week, in an interview with The Sun on Sunday, she said she wasnt bluffing about that.So why all the fresh scaremongering now The government has also told us that no deal preparation is in hand so there should be nothing to fear.If this official thinks there is, what on earth have they been doing over the past few months The government is bracing itself in case supply chains creak or even break in the event of Britain leaving without a deal in  days.The eight feared scenarios being touted by the Number  official are a drug shortage, with a maximum of two weeks supply of medicines, border problems, including lorry tailbacks at Dover, blackouts, a collapse in the pounds value, sat navs failing to update, breakdown of the European Arrest Warrant, a huge fall in house prices and businesses pulling out of Britain.They have all been dismissed as scaremongering.Lib Dem MP Layla Moran, an anti-Brexit campaigner, said: It is clear the PM was blatantly lying when she said no deal is better than a bad deal.The list of consequences for the NHS, crime and jobs beggars belief.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle sister samantha unannounced palace visit
story: Samantha Markle, , was locked in an embarrassing stand off with police guards as she tried to visit the Duchess of Sussex after their bitter fall out.But instead of a chance to speak to Meghan, the American tourist was forced to reluctantly leave a note with the guards for her estranged half-sister, the Sunday Mirror reports.Samantha arrived in London two weeks ago claiming she wanted to speak to her half-sister, who she hasn’t seen in more than a decade.A source told the newspaper: “This was a huge move on the part of Meghan’s sister to try to see her face to face and the fact she was turned away speaks volumes.Samantha later tweeted about the attempt to reconnect with her sister, writing: Everybody would love to know what’s in that letterSamantha first hit out at her famous half-sister after her romance with Prince Harry was revealed, branding her a social climber who is not fit to be a royal.She then announced that she would release her memoirs and that her sister should prepare herself for some home truths.But it was after she was snubbed from the wedding that things really turned sour and she has continued to vent her fury with frequent Twitter tirades.Samanthas representatives reportedly sent palace officials a letter demanding a meeting and giving them an ultimatum - arrange a face-to-face meeting with Meghan or she would show up on her doorstep.The source said: “She said words to the effect thatthe Palace didn’t do something to help mend the rt now, something may happen to their dad, who is in ill health.The ­suggestion was thatthe rt was left unhealed it would be their fault.“She went to the gates and tried to reason with them.She explained she had been in touch with palace ­officials and claimed they had ignored her advances, leaving her no choice but to arrive uninvited.Samantha, who suffers from multiple sclerosis, showed up a few days later with her partner, who pushed her wheelchair to the entrance of Kensington Palace.She was hopeful she would be let in but they turned her away and she handed one of the guards a letter for Meghan in the hope that it would get passed on, the source added.They then bizarrely went souvenir shopping and is said to have bought royal merchandise - including Meghan and Harry masks.During her UK visit, Samantha appeared on Jeremy Vine’s Channel  show where she defended her decision to criticise her half sister from dad Thomas first marriage.Samantha said: “I would just say that there’s so much water under the bridge and so much has spun out of control that was never intended to.“I think everybody was hurt at not being included or invited to the wedding.“I felt it could’ve all been nipped in the bud had everyone been included and we all agreed to move forward with positive resolve.“The hurt feelings wouldn’t have snowballed but, believe it or not, it doesn’t mean we don’t love you any less.“I just think that families can be this way when there’s confusion and when people are hurt.“So moving forward I apologise and I wish things could be dferent.”

title: theresa may labour jeremy corbyn
story: The PM has made a bold bid to poach millions of moderate Labour supporters who dont like the way Mr Corbyn has transformed the party.She insisted that only the Tories are decent, moderate and patriotic - claiming Labour has abandoned its traditional values.And she blasted Mr Corbyn for allowing anti-Semitism to grow and undermining the fight against Britains enemies.Mrs May today used an article in the left-wing Observer newspaper to reach out to Labour voters.She wrote: Millions of people who have supported Labour all their lives are appalled by what has happened to a once-great party under the leadership of Jeremy Corbyn.Anti-Semitism has grown, the party’s response to threats to our country’s security has become equivocal, and moderate Labour MPs have become targets for deselection and harassment.These are all alien to Labour’s best traditions.The PM said her party now represents the political mainstream as she vowed to fix the faults of capitalism.Mrs May wrote: I want voters who may previously have thought of themselves as Labour supporters to look at my Government afresh.They will find a decent, moderate and patriotic programme that is worthy of their support.Downing Street officials have been reaching out to centrist Labour MPs to try and win their backing for the PMs Brexit plans.Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell today dismissed Mrs Mays efforts to grab Labour voters, claiming its a sign of her own weakness.He told Sky News: Its no wonder shes desperately looking for support fairly cynically from anywhere.

title: pregnant woman birth john lewis store
story: The new mum, said to be in her s, was in the department stores Glasgow Buchanan Galleries branch on September , when her waters broke.Paramedics scrambled to the branch at .pm, following reports a woman had already gone into labour and delivered her baby, the Daily Post reported.She was reportedly on the third floor of the store when she went into labour.Bosses have not confirmed whether the woman was a customer or an employee.The new mum and her baby, thought to be a little girl, were taken to Glasgow Royal Infirmary, but have since been discharged.The pair are said to be doing very well.A spokesman from the Scottish Ambulance Service said: We received a call at . on September  to attend Buchanan Galleries.We dispatched one ambulance to the scene and transported one woman in her s to Glasgow Royal Infirmary.Sun Online have contacted John Lewis for comment.

title: banksy reveals how he installed self destruct device into girl with balloon artwork years before 1m artwork was shredded at auction
story: Buyers at the Sotheby’s London auction house were left stunned when his Girl with Balloon piece started to self-destruct on Friday night.It sold for a staggering £,, but it was left hanging in strips when it went through the device which had been placed inside the frame.Banksy has now revealed he placed a shredder inside the frame and uploaded footage of him building it to his Instagram page, and wrote: “The urge to destroy is also a creative urge - Picasso.The footage, which has been viewed more than million times, shows the device being installed inside the frame before being covered up.He wrote: A few years ago I secretly built a shredder into a painting in case it was ever put up for auction.It then shows the moment the iconic piece was sold – and then seconds later coming out in pieces.The framed, stencil spray painting shows a girl reaching towards a heart-shaped balloon and had been the final piece sold, equalling Banksys previous auction record of £. million.Many in the crowd werent surethe painting would be worthless after seemingly being destroyed but an art broker believes its value has now gone up.Joey Syer, co-founder of the website MyArtBroker that resells Banksy pieces, said: The auction result will only propel this further and given the media attention this stunt has received, the lucky buyer would see a greaton the £.m they paid last night.This is now part of art history in its shredded state and we’d estimate Banksy has added at a minimum % to its value, possibly as high as being worth £m plus.Posting a picture of the moment on Instagram, Banksy wrote: Going, going, gone...Alex Branczik, Sothebys senior director and head of contemporary art in Europe, said: It appears we just got Banksy-ed.Banksy is a Bristol-born artist whose true identity - despite rampant speculation - has never been officially revealed.He came to prominence through a series of graffiti pieces that appeared on buildings across the country, marked by deeply satirical undertones.Fridays self-destruction was the latest in a long history of anti-establishment statements by the street artist.Rumours have long circulated about the true identity of street artist Banksy.A number of people claim to have spotted him at work but no sighting has ever been officially confirmed while other clues have been used to try and unmask the legend.Other recent works included the opening of Dismaland, his dystopian, Disneyland-esque theme park in , which he described as a family theme park unsuitable for children.Girl With Balloon appeared on a wall in Great Eastern Street, London.The gallery version featured spray paint and acrylic on canvas, mounted on a board.

title: children fairy tale cinderella independent women
story: Cinderella, Sleeping Beauty and Rapunzel use their own skills to create their happily-ever-afters in Fairer Tales: Princesses Doing it for Themselves.Award-winning author Emma Dodd depicted Cinderella wearing her own snazzy trainers instead of uncomfortable glass slippers, and going on to launch her own shoe company.Rapunzel refuses to wait for a Prince to rescue her by scaling up her hair. Instead she cuts it off to use as a rope so she can escape the castle herself.The new book sees Sleeping Beauty saving her pocket money before she sleeps, so she can wake up to huge savings.Psychologist Laverne Antrobus, from TV show The Secret Le of  and  year olds, said: “From early childhood, gender stereotyping through popular culture and the stories we tell our children plays a key role in shaping attitudes towards key issues such as finance.Ensuring that both boys and girls can see empowered female characters is important in building confidence and understanding of what girls can achieve independently.”

title: prince harry us ambassador tom tugendhat
story: Rising star Tom Tugendhat suggested sending the royal to Washington DC as part of a post-Brexit diplomatic push.He told The Sun Harry could be ideal for the job because his we Meghan is American and he served with US troops in Afghanistan.Mr Tugendhat made the suggestion in an interview with the Atlantic magazine where he also called for the Government to create a super-department overseeing all foreign affairs.Askedhis call was sincere, the MP admitted the prince would probably prefer to stay out of politics.But he told The Sun: Im serious about using him better, and the US is an example of where that could happen.We could use someone like Harry, in somewhere like the US, to say - the UK is back.Having somebody who could really cut through would be one hell of an asset.He does have an American we, and he served alongside US forces. The idea of representing his country is something hes done a lot.Mr Tugendhat, who chairs the Commons powerful foreign affairs select committee, also suggested the job of ambassador to China could go to David Cameron.He added: The idea is that these arent quiet poistions any more.The MP insisted Britain needs to boost ambassadors public profile so that the rest of the world knows the UK is back as a global player.He said football stars and artists could also be signed up as diplomats - as long as they had an experienced deputy who could do most of the technical work.Mr Tugendhat has urged the PM to use Brexit as an opportunity to look outwards instead of becoming more closed to the world.

title: parliaments cleaners complain after they find vomit and used condoms in mp offices
story: Politicians were compared to rowdy freshers because of the disgusting mess they leave around the place.They will be spoken to by Commons staff and told to do a better job tidying up afterthemselves, the Sunday Times reported.A source told the paper: It’s the type of behaviour you would expect from students enjoying freshers’ week, not MPs and their staff.Cleaners are being confronted with vomit and used condoms in offices used by MPs and their staff.Most MPs share offices with their researchers and admin assistants.Those who work in Parliament face being asked to sign up to a code of conduct promising not to misuse the premises.The Commons drinking culture has come under scrutiny in the wake of the Pestminster scandal last year.Parliament hosts several cut-price bars and restaurants where MPs and their staff can often be seen drinking late into the night.One bar was temporarily shut last year after two workers had a massive fight.The authorities have since tried to crack down on drunken behaviour inside Parliament.A Commons spokesman said: The House of Commons provides offices to MPs and their staff to enable them to carry out their Parliamentary duties.Any use of such facilities must be in support of those duties, as specied in the Members’ Handbook and Code of Conduct. Any reported misuse of facilities will be taken seriously and investigated.

title: labour could back four day weeks for all workers john mcdonnell hints
story: The Shadow Chancellor said his officials are looking into the possibility of moving Britain to a four-day weekLabour takes power.The Tories accused the party of threatening untold damage to our economy by floating the radical policy.Labour are keen to improve workers productivity - meaning they could produce the same output in a shorter period of time.Mr McDonnell told the BBCs Sunday Politics: We will be exploring a whole range of issues about automation - we will look at the working week.Askedthat could include a four-day week, the Shadow Chancellor said: We have got to make sure in the fourth industrial revolution that workers get the benefits of this as well and that might be reducing hours of work.“We work the longest hours in Europe and yet we are less productive. The Germans and French produce in four days what we produce in five and yet we work the longest hours.Union bosses have previously backed the policy, which would potentially see workers earning the same in four days as they currently do in five.But the Tories today blasted Mr McDonnell for opening the door to the change.Party chairman Brandon Lewis said: Labour again looking to do untold damage to our economy, which would hurt our productivity, reduce living standards and create higher unemployment.

title: brett kavanaughs appointment galvanises both sides of the house
story: Both sides are claiming they have been galvanised by the battle. title: sturgeon snp to support second brexit referendum
story: The First Minister was speaking after a march in support of independence saw thousands of people pack theof the Royal Mile in Edinburgh.Organisers of the "All Under One Banner" march, from Edinburgh Castle to Holyrood, claimed tens of thousands took part, though there was no official confirmation.The SNPs Westminster leader, Ian Blackford, told Sky News that Scotland has to have the right to vote on independence for a second time should there be a similar renewed vote on Brexit.Speaking on Sophy Ridge on Sunday, he said: "If theres a peoples vote, we need to make sure that our position is protected. "We must have the right -we are being dragged out of Europe,we are being dragged out of the single market and customs union - that we have that ability to determine our own future."The SNP Conference opens with the party claiming it has become the second largest in the UK, pushing the Conservatives into third place.Ahead of the conference, Ms Sturgeon said: "At this most crucial time in the UKs negotiations on its future relations with the EU, Labour and the Tories have fallen apart into bitter faction fighting."The people of Scotland deserve better than the despair, incompetence and chaos of Westminster.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey"" data-targeting-"" data-tag"" data-component-name"sdc-site-mpu" aria-label"Advertisement" id"mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance""

title: unilever shareholders bared their teeth and won
story: There were other criticisms, too. Unilever got the fright of its le when, in February last year, US food giant Kraft Heinz approached it about a bn takeover. This restructuring was seen as a way for the company, which has a Dutch chairman and chief executive, to avoid such incidents in future because the Netherlands has tougher takeover laws than the City. Mark Rutte, the Dutch prime minister and a former Unilever employee, did his bit to smooth the way by promising to abolish a tax on idends that made holding the shares in the UK more attractive than in the Netherlands.One by one, the big battalions of City fund managers, many of whom prefer to speak on an anonymous basis to the financial press, broke cover to say what a dreadful idea this was: Colombia Threadneedle, Lindsell Train, Schroders, Aviva Investors, MG and Royal London all publicly stated their opposition. With Unilever needing the backing of % of UK investors to go ahead with the reorganisation, it was starting to look like a close-run thing.Yet that was not the only dficulty that emerged for the consumer goods giant.The influential Financial Times columnist Neil Collins, the most vocal critic of the move from the start, spotted in the small print of the particulars sent to investors that Unilever also required a simple majority of shareholders taking part in the vote for the motion to be passed. In other words, a small shareholder with only a handful of shares would carry as much weight as a big City institution with millions of them.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey"" data-targeting-"" data-tag"" data-component-name"sdc-site-mpu" aria-label"Advertisement" id"mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance""

title: brexit trade deals could take
story: NewsBrexit trade deals could take years no matter what deal Theresa May gets, admits Europe ministerSir Alan Duncan also admitted people voted for a "concept, rather than a contract" in the referendumShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT NewsEurope minister Sir Alan Duncan "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email It could take years for Britain to sign international trade deals no matter what Brexit deal Theresa May hammers out with Brussels, Europe Minister Sir Alan Duncan admitted today.But the senior Tory said he could understand why people would be upset by the reality of Brexit because they voted for “a concept, rather than a contract.” Sir Alan told the BBC: “Trade deals themselves could take years regardless of what agreements we have with the European Union.” Lib Dem MP and Best for Britain champion Layla Moran said: Trade negotiations are nasty, brutish and long. After a hard Brexit the UK will not be in a position to dictate terms. “Alan Duncan has admitted the truth today that Brexit makes our trade hand much weaker. The consequences for the British economy will be dire in every sector from aviation to agriculturewe have to wait years for these trade deals. It seems to be the pot at the end of Theresas rainbow.  Sir Alan went on to suggest he could understand why some Leave voters might have misgivings about the final deal. He said: “There’s no doubt that at the referendum people were voting for a concept rather than a contract. “And now we’re having to define that contract. So inevitably some people will maybe say ‘oh I didn’t see that coming.’”

newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHundreds of dogs and their owners gathered in Westminster to take part in the Wooferendum March to call for a Peoples Vote on Brexit . Organisers of the so-called Wooferendum campaign argued that animals would suffer from leaving the EU, saying there would be a shortage of vets and a rise in pet food costs. The march backed a wider campaign for a Peoples Vote on Brexit, at which Britons would have the chance to vote on whatever Brexit deal Prime Minister Theresa May is able to bring back from Brussels.  At several Pee Stations along the route, dogs were encouraged to urinate on images of Brexiteers like former foreign minister Boris Johnson and ex-UK Independence Party leader Nigel Farage - key faces in the  Brexitreferendum campaign. The canines gathered in Parliament Square after marching through central London for a rally in Parliament Square. Peter Egan and MP for Walthamstow Stella Creasy were among those who spoke at the rally, which ended in Parliament Square.  Mr Egan, who has five rescue dogs, said: I think all the attention that can be brought to the question of Brexit, whether its light hearted like today, the better. The -year-old said animal welfare was his passion, but he decided not to bring any of his dogs with him to the march, describing them as hooligans. The political commentator Alastair Campbell, who brought his five-month-old Cavalier King Charles Spaniel puppy to the march, told crowds to keep fighting for a peoples vote. Following his speech to the rally Mr Campbell, , said: Its a very British sort of thing - people love their animals and there are serious animal welfare concerns with Brexit, but the reason I wanted to come is that I do think the peoples vote has got to happen.  He said that politicians were scared of having a peoples vote on the outcome of Brexit negotiations. Mr Campbell said: They know the will of the people is changing,Theresa May cant even unite her party around this vision of Brexit, how is she going to unite the country. Tfany Haynes, , a dog walker from London, took Welsh Collie Megan with her to the march. She said: I think this is a nice idea for a protest, its a clever way of doing it because dogs make light of politics and bring people together. People can relate to each other more with their dogs.  Political writer Alastair Campbell brought his five-month-old Cavalier King Charles Spaniel puppy Skye to the march.  Mr Campbell, , said it was her first-ever rally and he plans to bring her to the Peoples Vote March on October . He said: Its a very British sort of thing - people love their animals and there are serious animal welfare concerns with Brexit, but the reason I wanted to come is that I do think the peoples vote has got to happen.  The Brexit that is now on offer is so far removed from anything that was promised and far from it being undemocratic to have a second vote, I think its undemocratic not to.  David Elkan, the founder of Wooferendum, started the campaign a year ago as a secret protest by taking photographs of dogs with campaign signs and putting them up in public places.

title: john mcdonnell reveals labour would
story: NewsJohn McDonnell reveals Labour would scrap unsustainable Universal Credit as the reforms havent workedThe Shadow Chancellor said he had been listening to the experiences of those on the combined benefit systemShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video john-mcdonnell-says-universal-credit-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn McDonnell has revealed Labour would scrap unsustainable Universal Credit as the reforms havent worked The Shadow Chancellor said he had been listening to the experiences of those on the combined benefit system and that it was beyond saving. It comes as reports suggest Work And Pensions Secretary Esther McVey has briefed the Cabinet that families could lose pound a month as a result of Universal Credit. The Mirror revealed last month that the party was considering calling for Universal Credit, which combines six major benefits in one, to be scrapped. Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Margaret Greenwood told The Mirror in Liverpool Were not ruling anything out, because we think its important to be on top of all of the detail of it before making a decision.  She went on to announce a major review of the toxic welfare system, including universal credit, in a speech to party activists.  Until now, the partys policy had been that it would pause the controversial welfare reform and make changes to the system. But today Mr McDonnell told Sky News Sophy Ridge on Sunday programme: I think most people now are coming to the conclusion that it has got to be scrapped.  I have been listening to people over the last few weeks about the roll-out in their particular areas, Ive been looking at what the Government has said about how they are seeking to reform it. The reforms havent worked. I think were at that stage now that its not sustainable any more. Its not a system that can work. Its not a system thats providing the safety net that people expect when they need support. I think we are moving to a position now where it is just not sustainable. It will have to go.  I think we are moving towards a conclusion now that you cant save the thing, its got to go. Mr McDonnell also dismissed Prime Minister Theresa Mays conference claim that the UK is reaching the end of austerity. He said: Isnt it ironic in the very week that she announces the end of austerity, we discover that members of her Cabinet are being briefed that families will lose out on pound a month as a result of the roll-out of UniversalCredit
