title: 5500 brit troops high tech
story: News, Brit troops high-tech war games in the desert go on from dusk till dawnEXCLUSIVE: Elaborate training push in the hostile environment in the Omani desert involved  armoured vehicles, six warships and eight Typhoon fightersShareCommentsByDan Warburton:,  OCT NewsA joint operation between British and Omani forces in the desert is helping the UK prepare for conflict "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDeep in the dust and sand of the Omani desert, Britain is training for war at am. Monstrous tanks and other vehicles churn up billowing clouds as they rumble along in searing -degree heat. Infantrymen in full combat gear shyswtly deploy to face the “enemy”. At sea a huge Navy task force has entered Omani waters while RAF jets have made their way to the Gulf State. This week the Sunday People joined the Armed Forces in Oman on the shybiggest UK military exercise in  years. Named Sa Sareea , or Swt Sword , it involves , British personnel,  armoured vehicles, six warships and eight Typhoon fighters.  War games in one of the world’s harshest environments have one motive – to ensure the UK is battle-ready to join international allies to tackle threats posed by the likes of Russia and ISIS. Strategists are mimicking so-called “peer-plus” military heavyweights – like Vladimir Putin’s army – so they can counter the world’s most elite forces. From Goodall Garrison at Camp Shafa, Brigadier Zac Stenning, commander of  UK Armoured Infantry Brigade, said: “We face many threats, this is an uncertain world. “As the Army, we want to be able to offer choices to our political leaders and UK citizens that we are capable of acting.  “It’s very hard to predict where the next crisis is but we want to ready for it. We train our army for a iety of dferent threats across the world.” The joint operation with the Omani forces comes as the UK faces a growing threat from Russia in the wake of the Novichok poisoning scandal. Earlier this year our Services head, Chief of the Defence Staff General Nick Carter, said Putin’s forces were the biggest threat to our way of le in years. This week a four-strong Russian hacking team was arrested outside the world’s chemical weapons watchdog in Holland — while attempting to sabotage the Salisbury probe. And while Britain wages information warfare on the Kremlin, Brigadier Stenning, the commander of  UK Armoured Infantry Brigade, said the military was keeping its eyes “wide-open” to a number of global threats.  He said: “This is an exercise in facing what we call a ‘peer plus’ opponent, rather than lesser opponents. “We are trying to put ourselves against those that might be the best equipped, those that might have the best training and those who would give us our toughest challenge. “Over the last two years we have looked at dferent threat vectors. We are growing more confident about how we might seek to confront and take down those threats as they come towards us. “You have heard the Chief of the Defence Staff speak quite publicly now about the threat from Russia. That is a pacing threat and he has publicly stated that. We keep our eyes wide open. “The fact is the world’s very uncertain, there are a lot of threat vectors.  “We have threats from Syria, there are crises in Africa, not necessarily purely military, as you saw British defence respond to Ebola. “There are many challenges out there that we have got to be capable of responding to.” The month-long war game in Oman will include training rapid reaction forces to deploy in crisis zones around the worldconflict is on the brink of erupting. And they are working on high-tech strike brigades designed to practice st-century warfare, using advanced technology to topple enemies. The Sunday People rolled out with the Mercian Regiment as they began the huge training exercise.  In the dead of night the awesome array of armoured vehicles including Warriors, Bulldogs and Trojans, thundered into le. We also joined the Royal Tank Regiment’s Cyclops squadron in staging war games over huge swathes of desert. Around eight miles from Camp Shafa, platoon commander Lieutenant Niall O’Malley Pearson led an attack on the “enemy” – represented by the Household Cavalry set up in a formation typically used by Putin’s forces. Lt Pearson, , rounded three Warriors before speeding across the dust and sending sand spilling into the air. And after calling “Release, release, release” on the radio a fourth vehicle thundered through the middle of the unit to attack an “enemy” Russian T tank.  Lt Pearson said: “When I give the ‘Release’ order, it’s brilliant, it’s like releasing a pack of dogs.” The military outfit will travel  miles from the camp, at the base of the Jebel mountains near the capital Muscat, across the desert to a finish point near Duqm Port. Meanwhile Armed Forces Minister Mark Lancaster said the relationship with the Omani forces was important as “violent extremist organisations seek to undermine stability”. He told sailors and Royal Marines assembled on the deck of the amphibious carrier HMS Albion it proved they were able to deploy anywhere in the Gulf “ the situation demands it”.

title: banksy mystery man spotted filming
story: NewsIs this Banksy  Mystery man spotted filming exact moment £m picture self-destructedPictures from inside Sothebys in London show four people who could be Banksy as a painting self-destructed moments after selling for £millionShareCommentsByTristan Cork:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news weird-news video rare-banksy-self-destructs-shredder-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Secretive artist Banksy may have been in the room when one of his paintings dramatically self-destructed moments after it sold for poundmillion.A shredder inside the frame destroyed the artwork as stunned onlookers gawped inside a London auction house. It raised questions about how the device was triggered - with many believing Banksy himself was there to make sure the stunt ran smoothly. And Bristol Live has revealed that there WAS a mystery man there with a gadget hidden in a bag, which appeared to be the device used to start the shredder up. So we have two, possibly three, candidates for Banksy -indeed he was there at all.  The Instagrammer The first is a man pinpointed by The Sun . This man appears in the first video to emerge on social media of the scene at Sothebys.The video was posted on Twitter by American-based journalist and PR woman Vanessa Hernandez, and can be viewed at the top of this article. It shows the artwork emerging from the bottom of the shredder, and then pans around an incredulous auction room, where everyone has reached for their phones. The Sun claim that a man with thick-framed glasses, standing just in front of Vanessa, could well be Banksy. Why they think that is because seconds after the shredding happened, Banksy’s official Instagram page published a photo of the artwork that appears to have been taken from the exact spot that man is standing, holding his phone and taking a picture. He is also standing roughly where the person who filmed the scene for the subsequent reveal video on Banksys own website was standing.The Sun also claim that the man’s appearance bears a resemblance to other pictures of Robin Gunningham, the Bristol street artist that has long been claimed is Banksy, although how they can tell this from a blurred side shot of his ear, is unknown.  There is a second - and maybe even third - possibly, quite apart from a fourth possibility that Banksy wasn’t even there at all anyway. The second is another man, shown more clearly in Vanessa’s video, standing a couple of yards behind The Sun’s main suspect, who is also photographing or filming the scene - at pretty much the same angle as the first. Weirdly, this man also has thick-framed dark glasses on, and a suit with bright white shirt cuffs visible. He also has a hint of a beard, and also bears a resemblance to previous pictures of Banksy that have been claimed are the elusive artist. The man with a bag of electronic gadgets  And finally, there is a third man that Bristol Live can reveal is claimed to have been there - and to have been the person who actually activated the shredder. A photograph sent to Bristol Live shows what appears to be a man sitting in the same Sothebys auction house room, but with some kind of electrical device in a bag between his knees. This man has a distinctive white scarf on, and a wide bracelet or watch. He also has dark glasses on, and has a hoop earring and seems to be wearing some kind of hat, headscarf or cap as well. The image, sent to Bristol Live from someone connected in the street art world in Bristol, was captioned ‘Banksy’s little helper’, while the photo itself has the ‘side-eye emoji’ on it, asthrough a snapchat filter.

story: NewsBBC Radio  music festivalgoer attacked by mum who used daughter, , as battering ram against crowdNicola McGrievy, , bit and scratched Diane Delderfield after being called a "bad mother", a court heardShareCommentsByChris kitchingLewis Pennock:,  OCT NewsVictim Diane Delderfield shared a photo revealing the injuries to her face "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum used her eight-year-old daughter as a battering ram to barge through crowds at a BBC Radio  music festival and attacked a woman who confronted her.Nicola McGrievy, , bit and scratched Diane Delderfield after being called a bad mother at the festival in Hyde Park, central London. A Facebook post by Ms Delderfield showing cuts to her eyes and face was shared hundreds of times after the horric attack in September . McGrievy has now been handed a -week jail sentence, suspended for two years, and ordered to pay pound. Prosecutor Katie Bryan said Ms Delderfield was five or six rows from the main stage, where American singer Gregory Porter had performed, when she was attacked.  Miss Bryan told Westminster Magistrates Court: Whilst waiting for a particular band, what the victim described was seeing the defendant pushing a small child through the crowd. The small child was in fact upset. She said to the defendant she was a bad mother, believing the child was in distress. McGrievy, from London Colney, Herts, then told the victim three times to say it again before launching the attack. Miss Bryan said: She grabbed the victim by the top, pulling it down, tearing it and causing pain. She then described being attacked with both hands. Miss Bryan said DNA found on McGrievys sunglasses, which were knocked from her head during the attack, was later used to link her to the incident.  In a post on Facebook after the attack, Ms Delderfeld wrote: She bit my finger and arm and scratched my face. I fear for the safety of the child. Another post added: Security did not detain the woman and I desperately need to find photos of her. She had a small child with her who was constantly crying. District Judge Devinder Sandhu said: This was a horric display of violence on a woman who was at a family event. You were there with your daughter and this happened in front of your own child, who was present while her mother bit another woman twice, once on the arm, once on the finger, and scratched her to her face. This all happened in front of your own child and I have to consider the complainant, because from her perspective this was a sustained assault.

title: money expert martin lewis says
story: NewsopinionMoney expert Martin Lewis says stop buying presents and warn friends not to expect Christmas gts nowThe savings guru has called on people to create their own Pre-Christmas No Unnecessary Present Pact with friends and familyShareCommentsByMartin Lewis:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsopinionMartin Lewis says people have disconnected from the reasons we give gts "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Christmas has wrongly become a retail festival. Instead of a joyous occasion, for many the season of goodwill causes unhappiness, debt and worry. So say it loud, say it proud and say it NOW: “I won’t be buying you a present this year.”Many buy gts for others that they know they won’t use, with money they don’t have, causing themselves stress they don’t need. It may feel too soon to be discussing Christmas. But this conversation needs having now, before most people start buying gts. It won’t work to stop giving unilaterally, it must be done by consensus. We’ve disconnected from why we give gts. Gt giving was once a form of social banking. Take a wedding. Older members of a community, who were usually more financially stable, gave younger people gts and money to help them get started in le. Then as that couple aged, over the years they paid it back, by giving gts at younger couples’ weddings.  Yet Christmas is a zero-sum game. You give to me, and I feel obligated to give back to you at a roughly similar value. To fulfil that obligation, we often buy things we know recipients won’t want, just to tick the box. This tit-for-tat giving means most people end up with tat – cluttering houses, costing money, and filling landfills. It does no one any good. What about the gt of giving  Some respond with “the joy of giving”. Yet even that may be selfish, as it can mis-prioritise people’s finances and create a financial burden. Imagine that I know my mate Noella is hard up. To be generous, I buy her a nice pound smelly bath bubbles and salts set. Then… she feels obliged to buy me something back. The net financial effect is Noella has spent her money to receive the bath bubbles I gave her. If she’d been free to choose, she might have put the cash towards buying shoes or other essentials for her children. Therefore by giving her a present and feeling generous I’m shyactually dictating her spending. Sometimes the best gt is releasing others from the obligation of having to give to you. It’s time for us to get off this gt-giving treadmill.

He said impressed Londoners gave him huge amounts of advice on getting work experience and knuckling down in college. After hours of knocking, he was invited in for a cup of tea by Elizabeth, the we of Quintin Price, who is high up at global investment management firm BlackRock.  The impressed head of alpha strategies invited him to the office for the day - eventually getting him work experience, a mentor and ultimately a place at university. Four internships and a degree later, hes now got his dream job at in investment management in the heart of the City - a far cry from his previous le. Reggie said: I was still in college at the time thinking how can I do something dferent  What can I do dferent enough for me to see results that no one  will think of doing   I had the idea for a few weeks but it took me a while to muscle up the courage to get out and do it. When I got off the tube at Gloucester Road I just all these expensive cars - Aston Martins and Mercedes lining the streets. Everywhere you looked just looked like money. I rehearsed this pitch ready for when the door opened. And it worked. Born and raised on a council estate in North Woolwich, east London, Reggie said his dad was not around to give him advice or act as a role model He was excluded from school age , had brushes with the law and knew he was in danger of going down the wrong path.  The determined teen was invited to church by a friend and heard the pastor say: You need to come out of your comfort zone in order to see things happen. That night he saw the US TV show that inspired him and headed out to get advice. He said: I got there ridiculously early - like an hour early - as I wanted to make a good impression. It was interesting I was meeting guys from Oxbridge, LSE and Warwick - it wasnt until speaking to them that I found out you could get A*s at A-levels. The insight day was funny - a lot of people were confused as to why I was there because I was still in college at the time. I then realised I was the youngest person there and thats when my mindset altered and I realised something could really come of this.

title: woman gives birth middle john
story: NewsWoman gives birth in middle of John Lewis - and she had no idea she was pregnantThe woman was on the third floor of Glasgows John Lewis when she had the shock of her leShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience EditorHeather Greenaway:,  OCT NewsIt was a complete surprise for the whole family "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who had no idea she was pregnant gave birth in the middle of a busy John Lewis department store. Paramedics were called to the Buchanan Galleries store in Glasgow after the women went into labour. She delivered a healthy baby, believed to be a girl, on the third-floor of the shop before being taken to hospital for a check-up.She had absolutely no idea she was expecting, and the new arrival was a huge surprise for the whole family, reports the Daily Record . It is not known whether the woman was a customer or a member of staff. Mum and baby were taken by ambulance to Glasgow Royal Infirmary for treatment after the surprising birth, which happened on September . It is believed both mother and baby have been discharged from hospital and are doing well. John Lewis said they wished to respect the privacy of the mother and declined to comment. The little girl is by far the first baby to make a surprise entry, and earlier this week the Mirror reported on Milaois Murphy who had no idea she was pregnant until her baby literally slid out into [her] trousers .Milaoiss mum thought she had appendicitis until she went into labour and her waters broke. The -year-olds baby girl, Harper, arrived at just  weeks as an ambulance was en route to her Dublin home in the middle of the night.

story: NewsWoman who is eight weeks pregnant forced to live in tent after becoming homelessHellen, , is struggling to survive on the streets of Cardf with her boyfriendShareCommentsByNino Williams:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video eight-weeks-pregnant-living-streets-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who is eight weeks pregnant has been forced to camp out in a tent after becoming homeless . Hellen, , has been camping out with her boyfriend near Swanseas seafront as she struggles to survive with her boyfriend. Every evening, she says goodbye to him as he heads off to try and make some money for them and the forthcoming child, Wales Online reported . She gets left with their friend Fletcher while her boyfriend tries to beg a few coins - something Hellen cannot do because a police order bans her from asking for money in the town centre. Homeless man with terminal cancer gets heartwarming last birthday partyHellen said: “Six weeks I’ve been here. “My partner is out begging. We’ve had the tent slashed, people damaging the cords. “We’ve been banned from town for a week, for begging. That’s what we all do, but it is Freshers Week now, so they are clearing the town for students week. Getting rid of us. “My boyfriend’s been in hospital for the last three days, but he’s out now and he’s had to go begging for us.” The couple saved up pound to pay for their tent, but own little . They use the Civic Centre facilities occasionally, where they praise the security staff there for the tolerant way in which they are treated, but it’s not somewhere of her own she can use as her pregnancy advances. She said: “What toilet facilities have we got  “I’m a woman. We’ll go in there [the Civic Centre] for a one-off, butwe go in too much, security push us out. “I’m not too good at the moment. I’m bleeding now. “I’ve got a midwe, got a doctor, but there’s nothing they can do for me. “I’ve been living here six weeks, but nine months on the street. And that’s because of domestic violence from another relationship. “Me and my boyfriend have been trying to get on each other’s claims since August, so that we can get a house together. “He’s my partner, and we’re engaged to be married and to be honest I’m going to be with him no matter what. “If that means staying out here, I’ll stay out here. “We went through all last week that rain, and you can imagine we’ve been having it all. “I stay here during the day with my partner and during the night I’m here with Fletch, and my partner goes out begging. He’s just texted me now saying he’s got money, and he’s going to get some food. “I’ve got to have my partner with me during the day, Fletcher with me during the night because people do get aggressive. “It’s not too bad but we do sometimes get people coming down here when they’re pissed, being aggressive. Homeless man beaten to pulp by teenage thugs given new lease of le by kind strangers“Fletch will zip up the tent and tell me not to come out until they’re gone. “But then you’ll get other people who’ll come up and give us pound, pound, because they see us here all the time. We move, but our tents don’t. “People think we are begging for drugs, alcohol, whatever, but we are out here for a living. “There’s been times we’ve stopped people jumping in the water.” It isn’t the first time Hellen has been pregnant. She says she has a daughter she saw the other day. “I was by McDonalds, and I heard someone and I thought ‘I know that voice’. I turned around and she gave me pound but told me I’d have to beg the other pound for a bottle.” Her friend Fletcher, , has deep-vein thrombosis in both legs, and has suffered two heart attacks, and three strokes. He said: “We survive the best we can, without committing crime, which is hard. “I’ve been here ten weeks in this tent. I’ve come from Port Talbot, where they say they say they’ll help me with property, but I’ll have to find one first. They tell us to find something on Facebook - but how can you get Facebook here  “I’ve only got a tent. We’ve got nada. We’re third class citizens. The police don’t help or anything.” The unpredictable treatment by the public is just one of the ongoing challenges faced by people living on the street. Emergency shelter is limited. Charity The Wallich has a limited number of beds at its base on The Strand, as do the Missionaries of Charity, and charity Caer Las. It is one of the reasons that calls have started to be made for the establishment of a ‘safe zone’ in Swansea - an area which can provide sleeping space, a roof, and basic toilet facilities. Earlier this summer, something similar opened in Bristol - a -bed -hour homeless night shelter made possible with pound, government funding, which has increased the number of emergency bed spaces in the city from  to .  It’s an idea being championed in Swansea by Plaid Cymru. The party’s candidate for Gower is financial broker John Davies, who has for the past six years been working with night shelters in Swansea, and more recently joining weekly soup runs which provide hot food and clothes for the homeless. Pantygwydr Church in Uplands, and Bethel Chapel in Sketty, are two churches which provide support for the homeless. “It can be quite intimidating on the streets,” he said. “People are vulnerable, but they get treated in an awful way. They have to hide just to exist. “Sometimes they are not safe from each other, and sometimes they have people coming out of pubs who are drunk who start beating them up. “It is evident no-one is looking after them. A safe zone would be a place where they are looked after. It could be something like a portable cabin, or a converted shipping container. “It doesn’t have to be elaborate, just somewhere they know they can get a good night’s sleep, and know they are not going to get beaten up. “The cost would not have to be huge, and it would save the money spentpeople are arrested and have to go through the prison system, when they would come out more agitated.”  Another homeless man Daniel, first started living on the streets in  following the death of his father. He said: “I’m in a BB at the minute so I’m alright, but a safe zone would help. “It would be good from a social aspect as well, because it keeps us together. “I don’t get grief because I play it safe. I walk around, I’m nice to people, I’m nice to police. “But you do hear people saying ‘ you junky, get a ******* job, I’m not paying for your crack habit, whatever’. “I’ve been homeless about two years. I just come out of jail. I committed a burglary, drugs and that. “A safe zone would be handy. I’d say have it near the beach, you could put up tents there. You’d be helping the community and making people aware.”  And another homeless man, Dan, also found himself arrested for begging. He said: “I got arrested the other week waiting for a chip shop to open on Bryn y Mor Road. Two officers said I was begging but I didn’t have nothing out in front of me, I was just sitting down. “Instead of punishing us, why not help us  Because many a time they’ve said they are going to do this, do that, but I’ve seen nothing. “I try and find somewhere where it is quiet and out of the way, so I feel safer. “Sometimes I sleep on the Pantygwdyr church steps and also the Jehovahs Witness church, there’s a bit of shelter there. Basically, wherever I can find a bit of shelter where it is quiet for the night. “I’d love a place, like a safe zone. I need a bit of support, a bit of guidance, a bit of help.” John, who has been sleeping rough for more than ten years, agreed: “This place really needs shaking up. “There are more and more places being built for students, but what about us who already live in the community  “We often get abused. We have rocks thrown at us, everything, just for sitting there. “It’s worse when people are leaving the pubs. What we want is like a community club, or a community space. “There is nothing at the moment for anyone. Some of the police move us on, sometimes they don’t. “They can move us on, but we’re only going to go down the road, or somewhere .

story: NewsDog who lost all four paws after being dumped in bin crowned Americas most heroic houndGolden Retriever Chi Chi was left for dead in South Korea, but after lesaving amputations has helped tens of thousands as a therapy dogShareByJosh Saunders:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video therapy-dog-lost-four-paws-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave dog who lost all four of her paws after being tied up in a rubbish bag has gone on to help tens of thousands of people. Golden Retriever Chi Chi only survived after her limbs were amputated after she was left for dead in a bin in South Korea. It was thought she would never walk again, but now her resilience has seen her crowned Americas bravest dog. After being adopted by Elizabeth and Richard Howell,  and , from Phoenix, Arizona, two years ago, she relearned to trust humans and quickly adapted to a custom set of prosthetics. Her cheerful temperament and resilience led her to be trained as a therapy dog and according to her owners shes since gone onto help tens of thousands of people online and in person.  Chi Chi, whos believed to be four years old, visits amputees, elderly people and children to bring hope, as well as to reinforce that nobody, animal nor human, should be defined by their disabilities. At the American Humane Hero Dog Awards last weekend, she was awarded the top title of American Hero Dog out of  other courageous canines. Elizabeth, a stay at home mum-of-one and caregiver to Chi Chi, said: Chi Chi just doesnt give up, no matter what she faced. She is courageous, determined and resilient. She has fought through everything and inspires others to do the same with the challenges in their lives.  Chi Chi had a very dficult and challenging le, but rescuers saw her will to live and decided to help, rather than euthanise her. We wanted to give her the best le possible, at that point we didnt knowshe would walk again, all we knew was that we could love her and give her the best possible care. She cherishes every day and even when she is not feeling her best or has to go to the vet for a procedure she fights-on with a smile. She is happy and playful, she makes the most of her le every day and most importantly she had to forgive and learn to trust people again.  I am very proud of her and she continues to amaze me every day with the challenges she faces on an ongoing basis. Her ability to thrive and really make the most of every day is an ongoing inspiration. I am proud to be able to share her with the world and she basked in the spotlight, she was in her element. She was happy, with her ears perked up and loved every minute of it. It was great to see her so happy, and for her to be recognised as the gt she is. Chi Chi volunteers up to three times a week and on social media, where the family regularly receive comments and messages about the positive impact their dog has had.  Elizabeth said: She has helped tens of thousands on social media @chichirescuedog and in person. Many of them noty us of the impact she has had on them. People with depression have told us how they didnt want to get out of bed, but then they saw a post about Chi Chi and what she does motivates them. We have met amputees who she has helped to see le in a dferent way. One person told me thatChi Chi could carry on with four amputated limbs they could do it with one. Then with children, we are able to communicate important messages about disability and that people with dferences are just like anyone .  We try to show people that disabilities shouldnt define a persons ability or potential. They should still follow their dreams. This was the first time Chi Chi and the Howell family entered in the America Humane Hero Dog Awards, held in Los Angeles, Calornia. During the ceremony, thats due to air on October , she won the accolade of Therapy Dog of the Year and was also announced the overall winner.

story: NewsFish and chip shop serves up battered Terrys Chocolate Oranges - but theres one big question about themAdams Bay chip shop in Gainsborough, Lincolnshire, says the new treat has already been a huge hit with fansShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience EditorDanielle Hoe:,  OCT NewsFancy trying one of these "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA fish and chip shop is offering up a bizarre new treat just in time for Christmas - battered Terrys Chocolate Oranges. Adams Bay chip shop in Gainsborough, Lincolnshire, gave customers the chance to vote for the festive item they wanted to be deep fried. Terrys Chocolate Orange was the clear winner, and will now be added to the menu.The shop already serves battered mince pies and jumbo pigs in blankets, reports Lincolnshire Live .Owner Helena Papadamou said: We basically put a vote out on our Facebook page to decide what customers wanted battered this Christmas.  Items included mince pies, Christmas pudding and yule log but one big suggestion which came through was the Terrys Chocolate Orange. We tried it and it was sublime so we decided to make it our novelty item for Christmas. Its definitely more of a sharer. When we tried it, we broke it into segments each and the middle just oozed out all melted. It was very gooey too. But theres one big question about the unusual treats - how are you meant to eat them   Many customers have ended up making a bit of a mess, but luckily Helena has shared some tips. She said: You can eat it however you like. We have not seen anyone pick it up and bite straight into it yet, butyou want to you can. You could use a kne and fork or whatever makes it easier for you.

title: builder whose 150 home plans were refused says 550 folk overwhelmingly from dundee are interested
story: A housebuilder has hit out at councillors in Dundee who turned down its plan to build  homes earlier this year, describing their decision as “baffling”.Kirkwood Homes is appealing against a decision by Dundee’s planning committee to reject its proposal for a new housing development at Linlathen, north of Broughty Ferry in June.Colin Crombie, managing director at Kirkwood Homes, told the Tele he found it hard to understand councillors’ thinking, given that planning officers had recommended the plans be approved.He said: “We had worked closely and very well with Dundee City Council’s planning officers to ensure that this £ million development met their own policies, guidance and aspirations.“Once again, we were left baffled by the decision of councillors to ignore the advice of their officers, as well as the  notes of interest that came overwhelmingly from the Dundee area – interest that demonstrated a clear desire and need for new housing of this type in and around Broughty Ferry.”He said that, because of the support of planning officials and locals the firm “simply had no choice” but to appeal.The Scottish Government is likely to make a decision on the appeal before the end of the year.

title: can roarie be dundees deacon of hope
story: Former Arsenal kid Roarie Deacon’scoincided with Dundee’s first league victory of the season – could he be the piece that’s been missing from their Premiership jigsaw The -year-old, who signed from English National League side Sutton United last summer, has missed the entire start of the season after having ankle surgery.Picking up the injury in the final game of last season, the enigmatic attacker ed for the final six minutes of the club’s first league win of the season – at the seventh time of the asking – at Hamilton and, in the process, set up the second goal.And hiswas hailed by manager Neil McCann.He said: “Roarie Deacon I am really pleased about getting back in because we have suffered some real injury problems of late.“He hadn’t featured at all, he’d only had  minutes of football all season before Saturday but I knew putting him on he could secure the ball because he is so strong.“You can’t get close to Roarie and he turned the boy beautully, then he had the composure.“I have to commend the other boys as well because they were still trying to get into the box at that stage to get the killer goal.”Deacon himself was delighted to be back in action after his y spell out.A process that was extended after an older injury reared its head once more.His debut season was also curtailed by injury with a troublesome thigh problem picked up in December at Hearts keeping him out of action for a big chunk of the middle of the campaign.And, on histo training this season, he hurt the same thigh once more.Deacon said: “I had ankle surgery the first week into pre-season.“I twisted it and damaged ankle ligaments in the game against Partick and through the summer it didn’t heal itself.“The surgeon didn’t want to operate initially but it didn’t heal itself so we made the decision to go under the kne to sort it out.“I was supposed to be back a little earlier than this but on the first session back I re-injured my thigh, a problem I had last season, so I needed a bit of intense rehabilitation on that to get back.“Now, though, I am ready to go and I’m fit.”With goals being a real issue for the side – just four scored in their seven league games and half of them against Accies at the weekend – Deacon’sis a timely boost for the Dark Blues.In fact, he’s only played around six minutes this season but has already had a hand in a quarter of their league goals.Coming into the side struggling for goals and points, though, hasn’t ruffled Deacon in any way.And Dundee fans will be hoping his direct running and ability to go past people is the key that unlocks defences with tough matches against Kilmarnock on Saturday and then Livingston, Hearts and Celtic in the next month.The former Sutton man admits he’s surprised the Dark Blues find themselves bottom of the table as he s to fitness and has backed them to get up the table,they keep doing what they’ve been doing.He added: “I am very surprised, everyone is surprised.“No way we thought we would come in, do well in pre-season, and then come in and after six games not have a point on the board.“However, after Hamilton everyone is positive, you can’t not be because the way we’ve been playing it’s not like we’ve not created chances or played well despite not getting points.“Everyone is buzzing about in training, raring to go and wanting to do well for Dundee.”

title: closed dundee gp practice closes its doors for good
story: A Dundee GP practice has closed its doors to patients for the final time.Fintry Mill Medical Centre shut for good at pm on Friday after efforts to recruit more GPs failed.All services will be transferred to Arthurstone Medical Centre on Arthurstone Terrace.A spokesman for Dundee Health and Social Care Partnership said: “All health boards across Scotland are facing a national shortage of GPs and NHS Tayside is no exception.“Despite continuing efforts, Mill Practice in Dundee, which has premises at Arthurstone Medical Centre and Fintry Mill Medical Centre, has been unsuccessful in recruiting GPs to fill three practice vacancies.“A public engagement exercise was led by Dundee Health and Social Care Partnership in conjunction with Fintry Mill Practice and a report was presented to the meeting of the Integration Joint Board held on August .“In order for the practice to continue to provide the best service for all registered patients, the decision was taken by Mill Practice to permanently close its Fintry Mill branch on Friday October .“All patients registered with Fintry Mill Practice have been notied of the closure date explaining that after this date patients will be seen at the Mill Practice.”Fintry Community Council chairman Ron Neave said the situation was a “shambles”.He added: “This is a devastating situation for the community.“It is going to affect everyone in the community who goes to the practice, including the elderly, disabled and vulnerable.“The practice had only recently taken on patients from the Stobswell Medical Practice which was also forced to close earlier this year.“It’s a complete shambles. It means that people are now going to have to travel much further afield to see a doctor.”

title: dundee street artists to take on europe in competition
story: Dundee has been selected alongside street art centres in Italy and Spain as one of the cities to feature in a European competition.Travel the Wall will see artists from Dundee submit any of their spray paint artwork on the city’s Mary Ann Lane, with the winner bagging a trip to Barcelona.The alley, near Dundee Bus Station, contains a designated “free wall” where anyone can go to paint, mirroring spaces in cities across the world.Artists in Parma and Aberdeen will also compete on their respective free walls for a trip to Spain, while those in Barcelona will compete for a trip to Scotland or Italy.The competition is being organised by Wallspot, a body which promotes collaboration between street artists in  countries worldwide.Dundee’s involvement is being orchestrated by OpenClose, a project which has seen neglected spaces around the city transformed by artwork.Russel Pepper, a PhD student who set up OpenClose, described the competition as “awesome”.He said: “As far as I know, this is the first time Dundee has worked with other cities in Europe.”

title: neil mccann backs his dundee players to handle the heat
story: Dundee will have to face a dferent kind of pressure this weekend against Kilmarnock but manager Neil McCann is backing his players to handle it once again.The Dark Blues boss was full of praise for the way his defence dealt with Hamilton’s direct approach in the second half of their - victory.Accies brought on strikers Rakish Bingham and on-loan Mason Bloomfield as they bombarded the Dundee defensive line.However, with the help of the crossbar a couple of times, Dundee held out and lted some of the heat that’s been on the manager and his team after the six straight defeats that began their season.With Killie’s attacking line of Greg Stewart, Eamonn Brophy, Jordan Jones, Chris Burke and Kris Boyd it’ll be a dferent sort of pressure the Dark Blues will have to be ready to deal with.Neil, though, expects the edginess in their defending as they homed in on their first win to be gone come Saturday.He said: “The next game will be a tough one against Kilmarnock but we enjoyed last weekend because it had been a long time coming.“Against Hamilton, I knew they would go direct, they brought Bingham on and did go more direct.“You have to deal with that – there is only so much you can do as a manager, tactically, and the players have to deal with it.“You have to be able to deal with the threat of them going direct.“There was a wee bit of edge still in their game because I’ve been saying for weeks I’d love to see them go in front and see what it did to their game.“I always knew they would still be playing with pressure but they dealt with that.“They had to deal with long balls, there were a couple of balls flashed across the goal but I thought we were well worth our three points last Saturday.”Meanwhile, a Dundee reserve side including first-teamers Jack Hamilton, Darren O’Dea, Jesse Curran and Jean Mendy were thrashed - by Dunfermline at Kelty Hearts’ New Central Park.It was Jimmy Boyle’s men’s first defeat in the Reserve League with goals from Lewis McCann, two from former Dundee United man Robbie Muirhead and second-half penalties from Tom Beadling and Myles Hippolyte counting for the Pars.The match did see a first outing for new Dee signing Grant Nelson.The -year-old from Rangers signed up with Boyle’s reserve side before the contest.

title: private firm with profits of 1m last year hikes up cost of ninewells parking yet again
story: Visitors to Ninewells Hospital are set to fork out more cash for parking after another rise in fees was announced.Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd, which operates the facility’s car parks on behalf of NHS Tayside as part of a contract signed several years ago, will raise its daily charge by p to £. from next month.Annual staff permits are set to rise from £. to £..It follows similar hikes in recent years which have sparked anger among patients and staff.Indigo reported a £. million profit in , up .% on the previous year, due to “an increase in parking tarfs”, according to documents filed with Companies House.The company took on a contract to manage Ninewells’ parking in  on a -year deal.It would cost NHS Tayside millions of pounds to buy out the agreement, and both health and government chiefs have repeatedly ruled out such a move.Margaret Watt, recently retired honorary chairman of the Scottish Patients Association, said: “These parking companies should be ashamed of themselves.“They are targeting patients and their relatives at a very vulnerable time in their lives when people can be very unwell, or even on their final days.“Somebody should make these parking companies share these massive profits where they are needed at a time when the NHS is struggling.“The effect on hospital staff is also unacceptable .”Fraser Macpherson, Lib Dem councillor for the West End ward, which includes Ninewells, said: “These increases not only put pressure on the pockets of patients, their families and staff, it also puts pressure on side streets near the hospital.#Signing up for this contract, which still has another  years to run, was not the cleverest thing for NHS Tayside to do and they are stuck with it.”NHS Tayside said it would be inappropriate to comment.Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd had not responded to a request for comment as the Tele went to press.

title: Fee introduction was a factor in recyling rate dip but just a blip insists Highland Council
story: THE controversial introduction of the fee for emptying brown bins was a factor in the arearsquos dip in recycling rates last year.But Highland Council chiefs say it was just a blip.While the level of household waste recycled nationally exceeded the amount sent to landfill for the first time, the tonnage slipped in Highland.The regionrsquos  recycling feat of . per cent dropped last year to . per cent ndash and last year a pound charge was brought in for emptying garden waste bins. This fee was increased to pound this year.The councilrsquos vice convener Allan Henderson, who also is also chairman of the environment committee, said: ldquoWhile wersquore getting better at recycling, the change to charging for brown bins has meant some garden waste being channelled into municipal waste.ldquoI believe our proposal to build a lsquomaterial recovery facilityrsquo and roll out extra brown bin coverage will reverse this slight dip.The latest figures from the Scottish Environment Protection Agencyshow that recycling rates improved at  of Scotlandrsquos  local authorities.It estimates that . per cent of waste generated in Scotland was recycled, which was an annual increase of . per cent.Scotlandrsquos environment secretary Roseanna Cunningham welcomed the figures but said more progress was needed, particularly in the cities.The biggest increases in recycling rates were in West Lothian, East Renfrewshire, Dumfries and Galloway, South Ayrshire and Aberdeen City.Ms Cunningham said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has big plans for tackling waste plastics, in particular by introducing a depositscheme, to further incentivise people to recycle.ldquoWersquove also introduced a household recycling charter for local authorities to sign up to, which is making the approach to recycling less confusing for households and creating a more consistent and efficient system for authorities.The Sepa figures show the amount of household waste generated in Scotland was . million tonnes in  ndash a decrease of , tonnes from .Sunday  Oct  : PM

title: Gaelic centre plan has backing of Inverness public
story: A SURVEY has shown that there is signicant public support for a new Gaelic cultural centre in Inverness.The research, which was carried out by the Alba Heritage Trust with the aim of establishing the level of interest in a project celebrating Gaelic heritage, was met with ldquooverwhelming backing from members of the public.Alba Heritage Trust director Alastair Forbes says the reaction has from businesses and iniduals across the board has been signicant.ldquoWe are delighted to have had so many responses to the survey, he said.ldquoThe reaction from the public and private sectors and from members of the community for the establishment of a Gaelic cultural centre has been extremely positive which has given us great confidence in moving forward with the project.Dr Blackrsquos Memorial Hall in the city centre has already been earmarked as a potential venue for the initiative ndash backed by an architectural survey.Plans for potential facilities in the centre include a Gaelic cafeacute, a retail space selling Gaelic-themed products, and language classes as well as a cultural exhibition.It would also host ceilidhs, shows and performances, as well as talks and lectures on the subject of Gaelic culture.Alba Heritage Trust director Emily Macdonald said: ldquoA cultural centre of this type would be of great benefit to the city of Inverness and the wider Highland area.ldquoIt would provide a focal point for anyone with an interest in Gaelic language and culture.ldquoThe potential impacts include promoting Gaelic language and culture, increasing Gaelic usage, encouraging community interaction, attracting further cultural events to the city, creating jobs and enhancing Invernessrsquos offering as a centre for tourism.Sunday  Oct  : PM

title: Port cruises to best ever year
story: THE Port of Cromarty Firth recorded its best ever year in , with almost pound million in turnover, it has reported.Its annual review reports a turnover of pound. million ndash pound million higher than its previous turnover record in .A ersication from its core business of oil and gas to renewables, decommissioning and cruise and a higher number of vessels than expected resulted in the improvement. Many of the visitors have been taken by coach to hot spots such as Inverness and Loch Ness.The strong results will allow the port at Invergordon to continue to invest in major developments, such as the new quayside and laydown space, which is in the planning stages for construction through Chief executive Bob Buskie said: ldquoAt the start of , with low oil and gas prices, we knew the port had to adapt to sustain our growth and help keep local people in work.ldquoFirstly, supporting our core customers in oil and gas was a key concern.ldquoAfter the necessary consultation, we introduced a new pricing for statutory dues in January , which meant an average five per cent reduction in fees for most clients, supporting them through the downturn.ldquoSecondly, the port had to look to the future and see what we could do to help sustain jobs and growth.The cruise-liner market was a success last year, with the port being named as the busiest in Scotland. It welcomed  ships and more than , passengers mdash a  per cent increase on . The direct spend from passengers is put at pound million.The port has outlined plans to build a new multi-use berth development to provide modern facilities and to accommodate the larger cruise ships.The port also ran two workshops, in conjunction with the cruise companies and Highlands and Islands Enterprise, to help local businesses understand and work with this lucrative sector. A cruise stakeholder group was also established to help improve logistics and communication.Port board chairman Douglas Russell said hard work by its staff saw produced the record-breaking year.Sunday  Oct  : PM

title: Pressure on Highland Council to stub out unethical investments
story: HIGHLAND Council could review its stake-holding in tobacco, alcohol and weapons companies.Opposition to such selections was spelled out by Ross-shire councillor Angela MacLean amid long running anger about the ethics of the local authority investing millions of pounds in such industries while also claiming to promote ldquohealthy lestyles through council policies.Over the past  years, a small band of councillors has registered opposition to widely perceived ldquounethical investments but to no effect.Independent fund managers are employed to get the maximum . Recent figures showed the fund increased in value in - by pound. million. As of last weekend, it was valued at pound,,,..Addressing colleagues on the audit and scrutiny committee, Cllr MacLean called for a review of investment strategy. She acknowledged the need to secure the best .But she added: ldquoSome people are not happy with some of the investments and feel that perhapsitrsquos invested in tobacco or arms or things like that, itrsquos not ethically responsible.She asked whether fund trustees had any say in the choice of investments.The councilrsquos investments change on a daily basis.Recent examples of contentious choices include British American Tobacco , liqueurs firm Pernod Ricard , pubs chain Mitchells and Butlers , Japan Tobaccoand Chinarsquos second largest brewery, Tsingtao .The councilrsquos finance director Derek Yule explained that an investments sub-committee reports to a pension board which sets the strategy.ldquoIt is very dficult when some of the investment strategy seeks to invest in shares in companies not just in the UK but worldwide, he said.ldquoWhilst I totally understand some of the ethical debate, it is very dficult to draw a line sometimes.ldquoYou might take a viewhellip would you invest in banks, for example  They might not be the best investment, anyway. But I use that as an example because banks will fund these companies.ldquoItrsquos a dficult balancing act but itrsquos certainly within your rightsyou wished the pension board to look at the investment strategy.ldquoFund managers are given guidelines to work to, so that would be quite legitimate for the council to do through the pension board.According to current policy, the fund ldquorecognises that social, environmental and ethical considerations are among factors investment managers will take into account, where relevant, when selecting investments for purchase, retention or sale.However, it stresses that ldquothe overriding consideration for pension committee members is their fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and scheme members.The Scheme Advisory Board, established up by the Scottish Government to regulate such public sector pension funds, recently obtained advice from legal counsel on the duty of pensions committees.The guidance concluded that: ldquoPensions committees in Scotland owe a fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and the scheme members in general and specically in relation to investment matters.ldquoThose duties should be exercised in the best interests of the beneficiaries and in relation to investment decisions, should aim to achieve the best financial position for the fund, balancing risk andin the usual way.Sunday  Oct  : PM

story: Motorists are being advised of temporary road closures in Inverness tomorrowbetween .am and .am for the Proud Ness Parade.The temporary traffic prohibitions will affect all vehicular traffic under the direction of police.The parade starts at Falcon Square, heads along Inglis Street and High Street to the Town House, then across Ness Bridge and along the river to Eden Court.The road closures are as follows:Academy Street: closed at its junction with Union Street to its junction with Inglis Street, .-.am.Inglis Street: closed at its junction with Academy Street to its junction with High Street, .-.am.High Street: closed at its junction with Eastgate to its junction with Bridge Street, .-:amBridge Street: closed at its junction with High Street to its junction with Castle Road, .-.am.Ness Bridge: closed at its junction with Bank Street to its junction with Young Street, .-.am.Ness Walk: closed at its junction with Young Street to its junction with Ardross Terrace, .-.am.Ardross Terrace: closed at its junction with Ness Walk to its junction with Ardross Street, .-.am.Ardross Street: closed at its junction with Ardross Terrace to its junction with Alexander Place, .-.am.Bishops Road: closed at its junction with Ardross Terrace to its junction with Ness Walk Upper, .-am.Bishops Road: closed at its junction with Ness Walk Upper to its junction with Bishops Park, .-.am.Sunday  Oct  : PM

title: Recovery cafe celebrates official launch in Inverness
story: Our Place ndash or Ar n-Aite in Gaelic ndash will make its money serving cappuccinos and macchiatos to the general public, pouring the proceeds back into the enterprise.Staff at the Church Street hub will be drawn from a pool of ex-prisoners who agree to work for free infor on-the-job training.And pensioners and other do-gooders will put their green fingers to good use growing as much free fruit and vegetables as the cafeacute needs to feed its hungry customers.But in a slight hiccup managers at the Signpost charity which is spearheading Our Place are having to meet with some traders who voiced concern crime could rocketa high concentration of ex-offenders are put under one roof.James Docherty from Scotlandrsquos Crime Reduction Unit which is backing the cafeacute said the tradersrsquo concerns were ldquoa symptom of social exclusion.ldquoSocially excluding people is more likely to cause a rise in crime, he said.ldquoWe run a similar project in Glasgow called Street and Arrow. Itrsquos police-led but facilitated by people from an offendersrsquo background and itrsquos a blinding success.And speaking at the opening launch Inverness and Nairn MP Drew Hendry said: ldquoPart of the plan for the Inverness Cafeacute on Church Street is to use vegetables locally-grown by those who use the cafe and those who work in it, and its customers.ldquoThis is named lsquoGrow your own communityrsquo ndash how apt. What is really being planted here though is the new generation, the seeds of the next crop of people who understand inclusion, equality, community and respect.Alan Fowler, community programmes manager for Signpost said: ldquoWe want to create an environment where therersquos no them and us.It has secured pound, from Highland Council and pound, from The Robertson Trust.Sunday  Oct  : PM

title: Retail park plan aims to avoid major unit being left empty
story: A PLANNING application has been submitted to ide one of Invernessrsquos biggest retail units in two.Hercules Unit Trust, the owner of Inverness Shopping Park, has submitted a request to Highland Council to subide the existing Homebase store.It currently occupies the largest retail unit at the park and it was announced in August that it would be one of  Homebase stores from across the UK set to close.It is thought around  jobs in Inverness alone will be lost when it shuts by early . Job losses nationally are said to be in the region of  after Homebase entered into a company voluntary arrangement following "under-performance of the business".The applicant outlines that there is no demand for the store to be re-let as a single unit and iding the unit into two would help avoid the potential for a long-term vacancy.It is thought splitting the space would make it more appealing to potential tenants.Inverness economist Tony Mackay said: "If iding the unit into two makes it more attractive then that is a good move to make."I believe one of the occupiers is likely to be another DIY store but I do not know what the other store would be."The main problem for the retail park has been the increase in online shopping. This has been the same problem for retailers in the city centre."In light of a "city first policy" which encourages businesses to establish themselves in the city centre rather than out-of-town locations, Mr Mackay does not believe this will give the retail park an unfair advantage over more central stores.He said: "More needs to be done about the problem of online shopping on retailers. For a store like Homebase people were likely to drive there to get whatever they needed."The applicant suggested that despite the "centre first" policy this move would not be a problem because no new floor space is being created.The existing floor space would simply be split into two separate retail units.Mr Mackay said: "It is not the type of store you would be likely to find in the city centre. I would be surprisedthe council were to reject this application."Mike Smith, manager of the Inverness Business Improvement District , does not support the proposal."In my personal opinion I do not think the plan should go ahead," he said."One of the restrictions of the retail park was that there were only to be single units in section  of the Town and Country Planning Act. To ide the unit into two is going against what has already been established."This is my opinion within my role as manager and not that of Bid. I would consider submitting a formal objection to the Highland Council but I would first establish the wider views of Bid before deciding the most appropriate action to take."Providing the planning application is accepted, the two new retailers would still occupy a considerably large space.The applicant recognises that the potential new occupiers would still have a larger floor space than the other existing retail units nearby.The proposal suggests that a long-term vacancy would have a negative impact on the "vitality and viability of the commercial centre."Chief executive of Inverness Chamber of Commerce Stewart Nicol agreed that iding the unit into two would be a wise move.He said: "I think it would be a sensible and pragmatic approach to take."Sunday  Oct  : PM

title: Suitable site is sought to plant trees for Commonwealth project
story: THE publicrsquos help is being sought to find a suitable location in the Inverness area to plant five trees as part of a UK-wide project sparked by the Queen.The Inverness Courier has joined forces with city MP Drew Hendry who is among more than  MPs who will be planting trees as part of the Queenrsquos Commonwealth Canopy, a network of forest conservation projects to mark her service to the Commonwealth.The trees ndash two silver birch, two rowan, and a hazel ndash have been donated in a partnership between the Woodland Trust, Sainsburyrsquos and ITV which screened The Queenrsquos Green Planet, earlier this year.Mr Hendry, SNP MP for Inverness, Nairn, Badenoch and Strathspey, is keen to invte suggestions for possible locations and has joined forces with the Inverness Courier as it marks its th anniversary.People have a week to submit their suggested location and why it deserves to be picked. The Courier will then run an online vote of shortlisted ideas.Potential sites could include schools, community spaces, forgotten corners, existing woodland areas, or perhaps somewhere to mark the th anniversary of the NHS or the centenary of the end of WWI.Mr Hendry said trees played an important part in shaping communities and it was fitting the public should get the chance to suggest a site.ldquoPlanting of these trees, as part of the Courierrsquos th anniversary celebrations, is symbolic of the paper itself, and the roots it has in our community for the last two hundred years," he said."Trees are an important part of our natural and cultural heritage, and to our local economy. We are home to Forestry Scotland HQ, and The Scottish School of Forestry and of course, my colleague Fergus Ewing MSP, is also the cabinet minister responsible for forestry."Trees are also play a big part in shaping our communities, therefore it is fitting that members of the public, schools and communities get the opportunity to nominate a place where these trees can be planted, as part of the Queenrsquos Commonwealth Canopy, and to mark the Inverness Courierrsquos  years milestone.Suggestions should be sent to drew.hendry.mp@parliament.uk by Friday, October .Sunday  Oct  : PM

title: Time to tap into healthier lifestyle
story: Scottish Government ViewpointSCOTTISH Water has announced plans to roll out tap water refill points around Scotland over the next two years.Councils are being consulted to identy the best locations with the aim of having the first  Top Up Taps installed by the end of next March.The move follows the launch earlier this year of the Your Water, Your Le campaign in which the utility giant called for customers to drink tap water at home, at work and on the move as a way of reducing waste, saving themselves money and staying hydrated.Edinburgh will be the first location for a Top Up Tap with the installation going in by the end of this month outside the front of the Scottish Parliament.Other sites being considered for the initial roll-out include Inverness and Fort William.The units will be fitted with technology that will enable the company to digitally track water usage at each Top Up point.The resulting data will be used to calculate cost and plastic savings, along with the volume of water being consumed.Douglas Millican, Scottish Water chief executive, said: "Our research shows that people feel very positively towards the quality of Scotlands tap water ndash now these state-of-the-art taps can provide access to enable water drinkers to enjoy it while on the go by carrying and using refillable bottles."A national drive to encourage people to stay hydrated by drinking water from the tap in refillable bottles was set out in the Scottish Governments Programme for Government -. Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham said she is delighted to see it being implemented so swtly.She said: "By encouraging people to top up from the tap using refillable bottles, we will help cut down on our use of plastics and promote the benefits of hydration building on Scottish Waters Your Water, Your Le campaign."I now look forward to refilling my bottle at the Top Up Tap outside the parliament in the coming months."The Your Water, Your Le campaign aims to make tap the first choice for water drinkers wherever they are, and encourages businesses to make it readily available for staff and customers.Water samples will be tested every two minutes, on average, to ensure that quality is maintained.Licensed premises are legally bound to serve tap water on request, yet research shows Scots are uncomfortable asking, something this campaign hopes to change. Customer research by Scottish Water revealed tap is the water of choice for almost two thirds of people in Scotland , and currently over a thirdcarry reusable bottles always or often when out and about. But less than a thirdsaid theyd be happy to go into a cafeacute and ask for their bottle to be filled.On average a litre bottle of water costs about p, so topping up daily from the tap, could save pound. a day, nearly pound a year.The Top Up Taps are made from marine-grade steel and are connected to the mains water supply.* For further information visit www.yourwateryourleSunday  Oct  : PM

title: Treasure found in a 1 box of goods
story: AMATEUR antiques collector Simon Grech took a punt when he spotted a box of bric-a-brac at Dingwall Auction Mart on sale for pound.But the Highland Council community warden was stunned to find buried beneath the chipped crockery and tea pots a beautul slate box hand-made by a -year-old African prisoner more than  years ago while he languished in a camp during the Boer War.The artefact, which has the prisonerrsquos initials SJP Venter scratched on its underside and is inscribed with the name Bellevue Kamp and the dates  and , is being snapped up by a notable London specialist.The expert, who collects Boer War memorabilia, has offered Mr Grech pound for the box, which is engraved with a South African folk flower mot and topped with an intricate quail bird.Mrs Grechrsquos we Marianne, who traced details about the boxrsquos original owner, said it was a "really exciting find".She said: "Simon likes to visit the Dingwall Auction Mart because he collects and fixes clocks."He came home with this box and the prisoner of war box was stuffed inside. It caught my eye so we did some research and it seems to have been made by a -year-old prisoner who was locked up in the Bellevue Kamp for prisoners of war in Simonstown, South Africa, during the Boer War."But we donrsquot know what happened to him or how the box came to be in Scotland, and we would love to find out."The couple, who stay at Balnacraig Road at Dalneigh in Inverness, contacted The Anglo-Boer War Museum in Bloemfontein, the only museum in the world dedicated solely to the Anglo-Boer Wars of  to , and they gleaned some interesting information.A historian told the couple a large number of Boers were captured in the vicinity of the Brandwater Basin in July and August of .A quick run through the names on the Bellevue Kamprsquos prisoner database reveals that Stephanus Johannes P Venter, a -year-old man from the Wepener District, was captured at Fouriesburg in July .But the young prisonerrsquos fate may never be known because no more details are held.The historian described the item as "a beautul slate box" and said it had signicant historical importance.Mrs Grechsaid it was a good thing Mr Venter had scratched his name on the box."Irsquod never have tracked this poor young guy right down to the day he was captured," she said.Praising her husbandrsquos nose for buried treasure she said: "Hersquos done really well. Hersquos only been going to the auction mart for a few months, itrsquos just a hobby, but he came back with a painting of The Alps for pound which Irsquove had valued at pound."However, she said some of his other finds were rather more questionable."The other week he bought a piano. I said lsquothatrsquos great, how are we going to get it home rsquo."He said lsquowell it was only pound, I couldnrsquot resist itrsquo."Sunday  Oct  : PM

title: Tribute to tragic dad raises thousands for charity
story: A BLACK Isle family left devastated after their -year-old son took his own le last year weeks after the birth of his son have raised thousands of pounds for suicide support lines in a fundraising drive.Wendy and James Mulleryrsquos son James, a father-of-three, was struggling with anxiety and depression.The Cromarty-based couple, together with Jamesrsquos partner Jodie, launched a fundraising campaign and a support group to help others.There has been a positive response from people facing similar trauma.The threesome, joined by friends of James, climbed the highest mountains of England, Scotland and Wales within  hours in what is known as the Three Peaks Challenge.They raised pound., of which pound went to the Inverness suicide support helpline called Mikeysline and the remainder was donated to The Campaign Against Living Miserably, a leading movement against male suicide.Mr Mullery , a commercial waste manager for Highland Waste Services in Invergordon said the challenge, completed on June  was emotionally tough.He said: "It was when we got to the third peak that it really hit me."We raised a bottle of beer to James. We just remembered him and talked about him, it was quite emotional all the way down."It was a very hard thing to do but also very rewarding and at the end of it we raised a lot of money for good causes so something good is going to come out of this."The family set up Jamesrsquos Support Group, a monthly meet-up at the Mercure Hotel in Church Street, Inverness for anyone affected by bereavement or who is supporting someone who is suicidal. Anyone wanting more information about the support group meetings can call   .Mikeysline founder Ron Williamson said he was "very grateful" for the donation.The next meeting of Jamesrsquos Support Group is on Sunday, October  at pm.Sunday  Oct  : PM

title: USA dream awaits talented cheerleaders
story: SIX athletes from a local cheer and dance club will represent their country in America next year.Cheerleaders from Campbell Cheer and Dance have been specially selected to represent Team Scotland at the ICU World Cheer leading Championships in Orlando in the spring.The girls stepping up to the challenge are Hannah Riddoch , Lily Cameron , Briagh McMaster , Sophie Mapplebeck , Hollie Worthing , Marianna MacLean .Coach Dianne Campbell said: "I have been coaching some of the girls since they were three-years-old. It is amazing to see all their hard work pay off and to see their dreams come true."The whole club is incredibly proud of them and we are all there to support them every step of the way."It is such an amazing opportunity and all I want for them is to enjoy the experience and to do themselves proud."To qualy for the competition next year the girls auditioned in Glasgow in August this year where they were successful in impressing a  of five judges. They had to prepare a one minute routine showcasing their most advanced skills. They also had to perform a set routine that was taught to them on the day.Some  athletes from across Scotland will be competing at the ICU, where eight dferent types of cheerleading categories will feature Scottish representation.Hollie Worthing and Sophie Mapplebeck qualied for Junior Pom. Briagh McMaster, Hannah Riddoch, Mariana MacLean and Lily Cameron qualied for Senior Jazz.The girls will be competing against cheerleading teams from all over the world against teams like Mexico, Japan and Russia.The girls entering the competition next year will need to raise pound each ahead of the competition.They will also be training in Glasgow each week and need funds for travel, accommodation expenses and for the trip itself.To support the girls in their fundraising efforts ahead of the competition next year, donations can be made by contacting the clubrsquos website at www.campbellcheerCoach Dianne Campbell said training is already underway for the competition, which runs from April  to .Sunday  Oct  : PM

title: aberdeen blow away st mirren 4 1 at pittodrie
story: ABERDEEN rediscovered their cutting edge in attack as they overcame  St Mirren - at Pittodrie.The Reds were without first choice strikers James Wilson, on loan from Manchester United, and Stevie May through injury.However Sam Cosgrove and teenager Connor McLennan, on his debut, both laid down a marker by netting impressive first goals for the Dons.Both scored in  the first half before on loan Derby County left-back Max Lowe made it - going into the break.Cosgrove increased his tally in the second half to make it - before Buddies grabbed a consolation.It was a bitter sweet first start for McLennan who had to come off with a shoulder injury in the th minute after falling awkwardly during a challenge from Cammy MacPherson.The absence of Wilson and May was two of four changes  to the side that lost - to Celtic at Parkhead last Saturday.Boss Derek McInnes handed a first start to -year-old striker McLennan who  grabbed his chance.The teen#s only game time for the first team this season had been the last  minutes of the - BetFred Cup win over St Mirren at Pittodrie.Cosgrove also ed to the starting line-up along with on loan Derby County left-back Max Lowe.Having recovered from a knee injury that had ruled him out of the last three matches midfielder Lewis Ferguson also went straight back into the starting XI,Scotland international defender Scott McKenna was suspended having been handed a controversial two game ban retrospectively for a challenge on Celtic#s Odsonne Edouard.Northern Ireland cap Niall McGinn was also ruled out through injury.St Mirren created the first opportunity in the eighth minute when Simeon Jackson drove at goal before firing just wide from  yards.Aberdeen#s first signicant opportunity came when a Max Lowe drive from  yards was deflected wide of the St Mirren goal by Cosgrove.Next they threatened via a powerful low  yard drive from Gary Mackay-Steven in the st minute that flashed inches wide of keeper Craig Samson#s goal.The opener came in the th minute when Shay Logan whipped in a cross from the right into the penalty area.COSGROVE met the ball with a ing header at full stretch and brilliantly directed it into the far corner beyond keeper  Samson.Only the woodwork stopped it being - moments later when Mackay-Steven danced over the ball and then unleashed a  yard curling effort that cracked off the far post.Teenager MCLENNAN marked his first start in style with a superb goal.He collected a Logan pass on the half-turn and bent a magnicent  yard drive that crashed off the underside of the bar and over the line.It was - and game over for a broken St Mirren in the st minute when Mackay-Steven’s shot deflected to Max LOWE who was left completely unmarked with the goal beckoning.He calmly slotted in from  yards.Aberdeen should have been awarded a penalty in the rd minute when McLennan broke from the left flank into the box.He was pulled back by Jack Baird in the box who clearly impeded him as McLennan fired off a shot. Referee Alan Muir waved play on.In the th minute McLennan went on a rampaging run down the left flank, alluded three challenges before rling a powerful drive into the side netting.Moments later Aberdeen nearly conceded a bizarre goal when Lewis# clearance richoched off the back of Jackson.The ball spun up towards goal and Lewis had to race back to palm the ball off the line. He redeemed his mistake with a superb save.Unfortunately goal scorer McLennan was taken off with a shoulder injury in the th minute having fallen awkwardly after a tackle. He was replaced by Chris Forrester.It was - in the th minute when COSGROVE latched onto a cross from the byline from Lowe who whipped in an instinctive left footed shot.Keeper Samson got both hands onto the waist high shot and pushed it onto the post and it went over the line.St Mirren grabbed a consolation in the th when the Aberdeen defence switched off and former Don Cammy Smith picked up consolation and crossed to JACKSON who was unmarked and dinked it over Lewis.Aberdeen: Lewis, Logan, Devlin, Considine, Lowe, Ball, Shinnie, Ferguson, Mackay-Steven, McLennan, Cosgrove.Subs: Forrester , Gleeson , Anderson Subs not used: Cerny, Campbell, Mackenzie, E. Ross.ST MIRREN: Samson, P. McGinn, S. McGinn, Flynn, Jackson, Baird, Hodson, Edwards, MacPherson, Ferdinand, Hammill.Subs: McShane , Smith Subs not used: Lyness, Heaton, Kirkpatrick,  Jamieson, Erhahon.Referee: Alan Muir

title: gym and cafe offer kemnay residents social benefits too1
story: Kemnay residents can enjoy a good workout, a delicious meal and socialise all under the same roof.Café and Station Gym have been open for  months and have been offering a one-of-a-kind facility for locals.Owner Alan Findlater said: “This building is the first of its kind in Kemnay – we have the usual studio, weights and cardio but with the café there’s also the added social element.
